review_title: Coworkers were great, customers were the worst
pros: My coworkers were all amazing, kind, and talented individuals. The team was very supportive and it was easy to talk to everyone. The managers really cared about the team and it showed. The pay was nice, we received a lump sum discount ($500, I think every 1-2 years) and a 10-15% discount (also applicable to family and friends).
cons:
The customers were the worst part about the job. I was anxious to go to work everyday. Don't get me wrong, sometimes you'd get customers that were great and you'd get along with them well. However, it's the bad ones that stick. A lot of people will bend their phones or void their warranty and take it out on you. My coworkers were surprised that I didn't cry because of a customer during my time at Apple. The worst part about these customers is that they get sent a survey to rate you. If you get bad reviews, management will come to talk to you. 

On Christmas Eve, I once had a customer shove a watch band in my face and not say anything. No questions, no request to buy it, they just expected me to read their mind (I'm supposed to fix the phones too, not sell merchandise). I did it anyway so they wouldn't have to wait awhile. In return, I got a 1/5 star review without any comments.

Another gripe is the amount of work you need to do. You must do a minimum of 20 hours as part time. If you want a day off, you better be requesting that MONTHS in advance. Otherwise, tough luck. Best believe you will be working on all of the holidays. Black Friday is the worst.

Apple is not all sunshine and daisies as they make it seem through all their propaganda in their videos and training material. Nearly every employee realizes this after around 6 months. There's a reason why the turnover rate is so high.
- This is no communication amongst leadership and the team. 
- Your base rate is below the national average. 
- There is 0 work/life balance and leadership can not change it because of how scheduling is done. Good luck applying for leave super far in advance.
- They say there are no KPI's but you are expected to be selling Applecare and such otherwise they passive aggressively have "development" conversations with you
- There is NO room for growth. The ceiling is so low, and for the few positions you can elevate to, its extremely competitive with people from around the state usually fighting for one spot at a store
- You have to deal with employees who are brainwashed by the Apple way, nothing the company does wrong phases them
- The way the company talks is so fake, there's always a cheery excuse for everything
- You will never have your way because there's a trillion dollar company imposing its law over you
- Favoritism. If you're a favorite you will get elevated, or paid more. There's some shady stuff going on in this company.

review_title: Inclusive, listens to employees, good process
pros:
Good benefits, discounts, career opportunities, and they listen to their employees. I have never ran out of sick time or vacation time, even as a part time employee. They have a tuition reimbursement program. There’s opportunities to mentor or be mentored by people in the field you want to be in or help others who want to get into your field. They do 401k matching and there’s ways they give back to charities you donate or volunteer with, on top of their own give-back programs they do with nonprofits and community outreach.

Also, if you work hard and succeed they reward it. The better you are at your job, generally speaking the higher your pay and/or end of year goodies.
cons:
If you are an average or under performing or new hire or 3rd party hire, the lowest positions may not pay as well as some other lower end roles at other companies, such as a Verizon call center representative or Gravity Payments’ custodian, but they pay better than any regular wage job such as working at a fast food restaurant or a grocery store employee. If you are a full time employee, you can definitely live off your wages even if you have a family. With all the benefits and extras, you will feel happy at your job. 

Also if you just work hard/be efficient/innovative, your efforts are recognized!
Advice to Management
I had a great Area Manager, my direct manager is pretty fair as well. I have also met other phenomenal Managers and Area Managers.

review_title: Go to Corporate ASAP after being in Retail for 6 months to a year.
pros: Amazing company, benefits and really shines on resumes.
cons:
If you're in Retail, get to Manager as soon as possible. The pay, bonuses and stocks aren't worth it until you are in those roles. If you manage to get a 'No' or 'Not yet' answers from those in retail leadership continuously its because you aren't retail management material (push sales and be political). You'll shine else where like Corporate, where there's a lot more development and creativity and hard work is noticed.
Advice to Management
Corporate Leaders are real people. They don’t fluff and they are straight to the point.

Retail Leaders are your politicians. They tell you what you want to hear and want you to push their store's goals and agendas but sounding like its a passion point. They don't develop. Thats where you have to realize it. Remember, its 80-90% development on YOU, not them. They are just using you to make their stories better for their next journey.

review_title: Great place to developing an engineering and design mindset
pros:
- Great corporate values to do good for the people and planet
- Top leadership cares and listens to the feedback 
- Stock compensation is better than most of the companies
- Learning is substantial as you learn how to stay focused and ship a product
cons:
- Internal movement is stifled despite what the senior leadership claims
- You need to inform your manager if you are interviewing internally
- Not enough avenues to grow after a certain point 
- Growth is highly controlled by the manager and director
Advice to Management
- Please remove the requirement to inform your manager when you are interviewing internally. Any employees who are looking to move to other teams for whatever reasons, risk their bonuses, stock compensation, and growth opportunities when they inform their managers. It is unfair and restricts the internal movement. 
- Please develop internal tracks to make it easier for employees to switch to alternative careers, such as program management, product management, and software engineering. Encourage hiring managers to hire from the pool of employees who have signed up any of such tracks.

Advice to Management

pros:
Working at Apple has a lot more pros than cons:

- Awesome benefits such as neat discounts on services and products.
- Health & Dental Insurance for both part-time and full-time workers (there's a lot more they offer)
- Stock option on a discount 
- Internships for employees
- Free financial courses 
etc. etc. 

Overall, what can really make or break a good experience is management within the store. Apple is a company that really cares about both the customer and employee experience. Growth and development is taken very seriously at the company, and as long as you work hard and voice what you need/want, leaders will help you achieve your goals. You gain skills and expertise at this job which you can transfer literally anywhere else.
cons:
This is a retail job which means that your hours will vary based on business needs. However, you can definitely adjust your availability to your liking as a part-timer. Expect to work every weekend. Like mentioned before, management within the store can make or break the experience at this amazing company, but not every Apple store is the same. Most personnel move to different stores with promotions.
Advice to Management
My advice for corporate is to pay close attention to high turn-over rates at specific locations in their retail market. Apple is a company that holds high expectations of their employees, and leadership plays a critical role in driving successful outcomes. Some leaders in different Apple markets have no idea what the heck is going on, and others are OUTSTANDING. It varies across markets. Overall, the benefits offered to Apple employees is truly excellent.

pros: It was a blast working for Apple. Makes for great conversation at parties. I loved helping people with getting their device tech issues resolved. I loved my co-workers and helping in my capacity as a Senior Advisor (Tier 2). The employee discount was helpful - but not awesome. Really good health insurance benefits.
cons:
Being a remote (at-home) employee was super lonely. After six years I just burnt out. I repeatedly asked if there was a way the company would support get togethers with nearby advisors so we could connect face to face; but that went nowhere. Eventually I found people nearby and organized an unofficial meeting and had a great time. Networking is so important, but Apple really didn’t support that for people who worked from home. Additionally, the KPI were used as a weapon in ratings. Using numbers and reviews that were out of my control to determine my quarterly and annual review “score” never felt like a way to learn what to improve upon. Constantly asking what I can do to improve in order to get promotions or raises fell on deaf ears, although my Team Manager referred to me as a RockStar. For such a valuable company, they didn’t really pay that well. In my six years I went from $14/hr to just over $20/hr but it was extremely hard fought/won and I was left to myself if I were to have any success. ZERO mentorship offered - little more than words offered by direct management. They don’t really care about you as a person. Oh, and if you want to succeed at Apple I was told by a ‘successful’ employee that you can’t have a life outside of Apple. They’ll say they want you to have work/life balance, but when the rubber hits the road you better be %110 Apple 24/7/365. I hated leaving but I needed to take care of myself and my family.
Advice to Management
Under Tim Cook’s guidance Apple’s Market Valuation increased at an incredible rate over the last several years. Perhaps he might want to help the workers (who actually did the hands-on work to get Apple there) live healthy balanced lives. At-home employees are treated like the forgotten. There are thousands of us!

pros: Good benefits and acceptable compensation. Long hours, constantly under staffed. Physically and emotionally exhausting but for some reason when you feel appreciated all that can feel energizing.
cons:
The difference between a great job that you love and a work environment that you hate is actually quite small. It is usually made up of the people you interact with. One bad local change in leadership can alter culture on a local level quite dramatically. Suddenly you find yourself unappreciated and the herd mentality of ‘yes men’ gaslighting individuals becomes the fulltime job — it becomes your life. Appreciating honesty and values driven decision making, must be central to Leadership. When it is not, you will find highly motivated, effective team members leaving. I guess in a short blurb that is easily digestible, that is the best advice I can offer someone considering to work in the retail environment. It can be a great company to work for, but when it is not — the politics of the organization will crush good people.
Advice to Management
The statement of culture and values at Apple is lofty, eloquent and could not be better. Take a closer look and assess if the gatekeepers of that culture actually believe it and live it.

review_title: A Toxic Place Full of Bad Apples
pros:
- Discounts on products
- Sometimes you meet some wonderful, brilliant people
- If a VP supports a project, it likely will be funded
cons:
- It is the most toxic work environment I have ever seen. Abuse and harassment run rampant. ER/HR are not there to help victims; they are there to gaslight victims and use victims as a scapegoat for when things go wrong.
- Apple’s values are all hollow and meaningless. They are just talking points for PR. Despite privacy being “a human right”, expect none as an employee. All those trainings about treating people with respect and dignity are laughable. Some of the worst abusers are also ones who get to speak at public events and announcements; there are never any consequences for their abusive behaviors.
- Chances are good that if you are a white dude with no experience, you will be offered more money than a woman of color with many years of experience. It is no wonder Apple has tried to stop pay transparency discussions among employees; the discrepancies are likely much worse than what has made the news recently. I also repeatedly saw white men being given credit for the work of women of color. If you are a woman of color, expect people to doubt your qualifications to the point of insulting you and your expertise.
- If you have integrity, this is not the place for you. Filing business conduct reports are known as “career limiting moves”. Without a good manager, you are SOL and will not have a chance of ever moving to another team or growing your career.
- Senior Leadership is incredibly out of touch with what their employees want and value.
Advice to Management
Do us all a favor and get rid of all the abusers, the enablers, and anyone else who stood by and did nothing over the years — and that means you, too, probably need to resign.

pros: The job is secure, that's about it. Discounts and benefits are just a trap to get you in.
cons:
They are hyperfocused on metrics and treat you as if you were a broken machine if you don't deliver their desired number. Their tools for measuring your performance are a mess, don't measure accurately and you still get punished. Measuring KPIs is a micromanager's best tactic when promoting a fear atmosphere in an attempt to "encourage" productivity but in fact, does more to provide hurdles than to provide a clear path by which employees can become empowered to use their creativity and skills to do their job well... especially in a business that depends a lot on your client's satisfaction to drive. Don't get me wrong; some vital statistics are important to monitor progress over time, but too much emphasis on KPIs has a negative effect and is counter productive.
Advice to Management
You must be able to trust your people to do their jobs and you must allow your people to do their jobs. Forcing KPIs down people's throats changes your employees' focus from your client's satisfaction to attempting to achieve benchmarks that may not necessarily promote growth. Your workforce then becomes intent on satisfying internal goals rather than satisfying the client and thereby increasing revenue. 

The best way to get the best out of good employees, to tap into what makes people want to come to work, to get focused on the mission NOT on useless KPIs which become a target in themselves and result in demotivated employees, the death of creativity and high levels of staff turnover.

review_title: Company with zero empathy and engineering best practices
pros: Name. Pay (if you negotiate well and have competing offers from companies like Facebook, google, etc. Apple discounts. Stable and promising stock.
cons:
If you’re a software engineer this isn’t a place to be. The work life balance is not existent for very bad reasons. That’s only because you won’t be able to use or build tools that can make your life easier. 

The over culture is very bureaucratic and there’s literally no check on the bad managers. In my experience they don’t care about teams success and there interests lie elsewhere. Few of them are downright psychotic - foster toxic environment, bullying, threatening, etcetera. 

Very, very hard to move internally. You have to let you current manager know before you make a contact with the future Hiring managers. The toxic managers may block your move if you don’t play ball despite having good reviews.

The benefits are awful as compared to other large tech companies. Heck even start-ups! You get 11 days PTO for working the whole year. They do have Christmas shutdown but everyone is forced to work to hit the deadlines that follow after the shutdown.
Advice to Management
Just fire the toxic losers who don’t get anything done. Looks for teams that are revolving doors and identify what’s the reason. Almost all of the times it’s the managers.

pros:
- Interesting teammates; people I’d want to spend time with 

- Cool work
cons:
- Non-existing work-life balance. This is not an exaggeration. People will email well beyond appropriate business hours, ping, text, email like they text. Weekend and late night work is expected. 

- Ridiculous overtime at no additional comp for salaried employees; this is “meeting expectations”. I’ve never been thanked or apologized to when interrupted on a Sunday afternoon. I have not had a weekend in a month. I did not get Memorial Day off, I had to skip Mother’s Day, I already know I will be expected to work Labor Day. What is the price of your time and life?

- Most execs and leads are men. My team is most female, on the ground level, while all leads are men.

I came from Google. It was an extremely tough decision to make. The creative is stronger here; there is no arguing that. That’s why I came. In comparison to Google, who also has peak moments of large work volume, my experience has been that Apple does not consider the cost and considerations of pushing for more work. The compensation isn’t as comparable to Google. The benefits are definitely not. The culture is teetering toxic. Essentially, on all other levels aside from creative and cool co-workers, I’d recco Google hands down.
Advice to Management
Want to keep your employees and reduce the burn and churn? Thank them. Protect them. Don’t speak on behalf of them. Ask them how they’re doing. Create small team culture where they are unofficial afternoons off, to balance the exorbitant amount of overtime.

review_title: Go to any other store but this one
pros: With Apple, this job does great to take care of you with their benefits, even for part timers. The coworkers there are great and they are very open and friendly with open minds.
cons:
Once the store went flagship they really started to care less and less about their workers and see you as a number. 

This specific store location is not a model Apple location to work at. I would suggest transferring to another store or starting somewhere else entirely. The management here really don't listen to HEAR you out, but continue to speak to speak their spiel.

They promote by favoritism, they don't give equal opportunities to try new roles as they preach they do, instead the managers will push for someone they prefer instead of giving and letting everyone know on the website itself when they're looking to fill in a new role or experience. Someone was here for a few months and got promoted to lead, and only to be gone within the next couple of month. Someone else was newly hired and soon promoted within a few months, because they had relations with a previous manager. I've seen people work their butts off, produce amazing results, and they're ignored because the management and leadership team doesn't think they'll "fit in" with their group. 

During the pandemic, when we opened back up there were things that clearly showed how focused they were on making money and not our safety, leaving cleaning solutions with no rags and taking out the hand sanitizers that were previously on the table (when we were closed to the public and only had a window store front, where there was less of a chance to catch covid mind you), then rush you when you try to clean and wipe down the products you and your customer were using, before taking another customer.
Advice to Management
Promote more people from within the company instead of bringing outsiders in to preach for our company's values when they're still unlearning their previous company's structure and models. The managers here are people persons, knowing how to talk but the support to find specific solutions is becoming more sparse day by day the more they hire from outside. 

Listen to your team and try to understand the process of sales instead of handing the problem to a team expert or pro and thinking that's that. It doesn't help the team if we feel like we can't go to you in the first place. 


HR had to be called so many times because of how your true colors showed, especially opening our store back up during the peak of the Delta Variant of Covid.

Learn the procedures, or even take a customer yourself to show us what you would do better and how you would do it, instead of half listening to interactions and only putting negative input.

You're draining everyone's energy and this is why people go on leaves or leave this store.

And where do you guys go to hide during peak times when we need you?

review_title: Great compared to most retail, but still just a retail job
pros:
-Pay is relatively above average, part time employees get all benefits, employee stock purchase program is a huge plus
-Education assistance, gym membership rebate, doctors, lawyers, therapy, among many other discounted and/or free services (even as just a part time employee! use these!!)
-Not commission based so I don't necessarily feel pressured to upsell products that the customer doesn't need (exception: see cons)
- Get to be surrounded by Apple products all day (as an Apple fan-boy, this was great)
- Great to talk apple products all day with customers, actually try to find the best product variation for them and learning about new and different ways people use their computers and devices
- Discount is great, almost bad due to how much I used it
- A great way to get into Apple Corporate, using "Career Experiences" where you work for corporate for a limited time and possibly get offered a full time job. Apple Retail while going to college is a easy decision to make if you're goal is eventually Apple Corporate.
- Relatively flexible schedule, flexible management
- Having Apple on your resume automatically puts you to the top of the resume list of your next employer (relatively speaking of course, that alone won't do much if you aren't capable of your next opportunity)
- Learn a lot of Apple products to use later in life for yourself and others
cons:
I joined in 2020, so I am not sure how things were before, but I had a lot of people tell me Apple Retail was not as "sales-y" as it has become with its services, especially AppleCare. I understand we have metrics to meet as a public company, but at times, it felt no different than being a commission-based employee with how often they pressured us to sell AppleCare and get Business Intros.
-While Apple is overall a great place to work relatively speaking, it is still just a retail job. Meaning you're co-workers aren't all going to be apple-fanantics who love Apple products and everything about their job. Its going to be like every other job where there are the try-hards, the normal people, and the lazy people. There are going to be bosses who are overly micro-manage-y and some managers who are just great and everything I would want in a manager.
- There are a lot of conflict of interests and policies around technology development and working at other technology jobs. Make sure you have no plans of developing any software while working for Apple unless you plan to let Apple own it. 
- We have a bad habit of letting rude and loud customers get what they want and giving the nice customers who actually deserve an exception a hard time. Really hated appeasing rude and obnoxious customers. Really hated turning down exceptions to customers who asked nicely and were in a situation that warranted an exception. 
- Its easy to sip the Apple Juice, try to remain un-biased and see through the Corporate bs. (But don't become one of the grudegy twitter anon accounts, they're over exaggerating and taking for granted their job at a RETAIL STORE).
Advice to Management
Relax on the AppleCare metrics. A large part of the reason I love Apple and wanted to work for Apple was because I knew I wouldn't have to upsell things to customers that they don't need. Even when customers had relatively good arguments for not getting AppleCare, I would also be told by leadership a phrase or strategy for turning it around on the customer and making it seem like AppleCare was good for them. Sometimes, customers just don't need it.

review_title: Run far away from the RCC deptartment in Austin, TX
pros: The pay is okay, great benefits, discounted price on Apple stocks, 401k that is matched up to 6 percent, discounts on Apple products.
cons:
Over the years, the RCC department (Retail Contact Center), formerly known as the Apple Online Store department, has gone from an okay place to work to a horrible place to work. I had worked in the department since 2007 and left in 2021. My team was the order administration team. My team did back-end customer service, and people liked the job since you did not get inbound phone calls. However, we would, on occasion, have to call customers. Most of our contact with customers was via email. 

About two years ago, management decided to combine our team with the service teams, which are on the phone. Once this happened, things started going downhill. Management wanted to transform the job to taking phone calls all day which nobody liked. We also were required to take senior customer service calls. Senior customer service’s job is to speak to angry customers all day long and resolve their problems. Once we were required to be trained in senior customer service, I decided to leave.

Another big problem is that there is no room for advancement. I had several interviews over the years, and nothing ever materialized. If a job is posted at Apple, they will typically get hundreds of applicants. If the job is decent, they will already know who they want to hire.
The only way to typically advance in RCC is if you want to become a manager. This is not a good job since you will be managing unhappy people. Apple also touts rotations as a great opportunity, and very few people ever get hired into another department. A rotation is when you go work in a different department and do a different job. However, you don’t get paid more, and you have to learn a new job. Most of the time, people never get hired and have to go back to their old position. Rotations last from a few months to a year. 

Woke Culture is very common at Apple. The old adage of staying away from politics and religion is not observed at Apple. You will receive emails about what Apple stands for and how diverse they are. At Apple is okay to have a sticker or shirt saying you support a Democrat candidate, but if you do that for a Republican candidate your days will be numbered. To be Woke, people would usually wear their BLM’s shirts at Zoom meetings. As I said, this is acceptable at Apple since this supports left-wing politics. 

Also, benefits have been cut over the years. Used to sick time was uncapped and then it was capped to 240 hours a few years ago. I also had for many years no deductible on my medical insurance and had to pay a copayment of 30 dollars. But a few years ago, Apple decided to charge a 300 dollar deductible on my medical insurance plan.
Advice to Management
None management knows it is a terrible place to work and doesn't care.

review_title: It's fun sometimes, but you will regularly be yelled at by customers for things outside of your control.
pros: You'll have great teammates, great benefits, along with positive and helpful middle-management team members who genuinely are looking to see you (and help you) succeed. The pay is pretty good.
cons:
You will be verbally and emotionally abused by customers on a regular basis. 

It is worse if you work for them over the phone. If you're in-store, your teammates may be able to assist you when it happens. They may also not be able to if they're busy, which they often will be. Either way, you'll have to swallow it.

If you can handle that, and don't care about working for an ethically confused technology company valued at above the total GDP of some countries, then enjoy your new career.
Advice to Management
Reconsider the nature of the roles your front-line workers fulfill. Do not treat them like sacrificial lambs, thrown to the fire in an attempt to appease/court the ever-elusive Positive Customer Experience. Follow through on the concept that you seem to recognize, though only ever half-commit to, which is that the people who work for Apple are valuable; if you genuinely feel that way, you'd trust them with the responsibility to advocate for themselves personally during negative customer interactions without fear of managerial backlash.

review_title: Excellent pay, meaningful work, draconian policies
pros:
• Excellent pay and benefits
• Get to work on products that the entire world uses
• I've never ever been denied a PTO request
• Working remotely on occasion is permitted
• Vacation time can be rolled over year-to-year up to a maximum of 30 days
• Company-wide, week-long holiday shutdowns for Thanksgiving and Christmas
• Sick time is separate from vacation time. You get 12 days per year, and can roll over year-to-year until you hit a maximum of 30 sick days. You can also use sick time for "family care."
cons:
• Corporate policies prevent you from publishing any code you write (even off the clock), distributing any apps (on any platform), or even helping out with open-source projects (including your own) without explicit written permission
• Full-time remote work is not permitted without an SVP-signed exemption, which is only ever granted for either highly valuable employees or those with disabilities
• Vacation time starts at only 12 days per year, and maxes out at 20 days per year once you've been there for 10 years. You cannot earn more than 20 days per year after that.
• You're not allowed to jailbreak your iPhone
Advice to Management
• Engage engineers more in feature planning
• Give engineers more advanced notice about new project specifications to be required by upcoming OS changes/features

pros: Apple gave me the opportunity to meet people, get trained in the retail store taking mobile service reservations, Great culture of family in the store. good pay, stock purchase plan and 401k. I did some of the best work of my life there. Learned to speak to customers, document their issue, diagnose their problem and set them up for success with a software fix or a hardware repair. I was certified to do phone repairs, Learned how to do all modular repairs on any iphone from 5s to current 12 pro. The day felt like it was always moving.
cons:
Your development is really based on you and what you make of it, You get an hourly pay and no matter how much extra effort you put in, sometimes you are recognized for it, other times it goes completely missed. Need to tell a lot of stories and recall interactions with customers for devolpment purposes. It seems like everything was very structured in a problem action result format. I was trying to go for genius, job opened up 3x and I interviewed 3 times.. every job I went for before this I skilled the interview, they hold the genius position to such a high standard because you get mac certifications... many people after some experience with genius leave for a better job. Seems like the best story tellers get the better jobs, very focused on inclusion and diversity. Sucks when you see qualified technicians denied and the not so great ones get the job based off of story telling. After being there for 2.5 years I felt stuck. I decided to resign. Durring covid I was greatful to not lose my job but many of us were forced into call center style work from home, my mental health suffered and everyone around me was struggling too, the call center training was a joke and the whole job was almost forced on us because at a point many of us wanted to come back to the retail store and were not able to, some were fortunate to be able to come back, but nearly loosing their job. others quit, others possibly got fired. my apple store was a shoe box in a dying mall. my store had no windows just a lot of people, always reaching capacity limits pre covid and after covid. Many store employees were offered experiences in corporate.. they did not get a pay raise for the work they did, they were only able to say they had the experience adding value to a resume.. could be a good thing, but many people did not make more money for the extra value they were giving.

pros: Great company. Cares about their employees. Good benefits. Managers work really hard to serve their teams. Need Up-ish energy to work here.
cons:
ant training and working on improving yourself. Good starting pay for retail. You will always be challenged to improve at Apple, so do not work there if you are at a place in your life where pushing to improve daily and lots of change will stress you. They are exceptional with inclusion. Respect is the expectation.
Cons
Worked there during COVID shut down 2020, so the hours were erratic and lots of jumping to different roles. Sometimes the communication for SOPs between managers could've been better. There is subtle pressure to be "up" about everything - more than is realistic for actual humans, so it can be a bit fake.
Still - overall a good experience. If you don't NEED full time hours to pay bills, it's a good place to work. If you need FT, forget it. You will wait years.
Advice to Management
Also, they do a lot of role play for trainings, which many people don't learn from. It's been shown that group planned "plays" teach with greater retention for RL scenarios, so why use the dated role play thing? It stresses people out and comes from dated (c1980s) training methods that were lazy. Give managers better tools.

pros:
Discounts, cool co-workers, part time was fairly flexible. Glassdoor is making write a minimum of 20 words lol for Pro's so i'm just continuing to type even though there weren't that many Pro's. Every 3 years you get a computer for like $500. If your 22 and you work here part time for two or three years, thats fine, but seriously don't stay too long, the job will rot your mind.

Apple knows the employees have a high turnover rate (80%) within a year. They know the employees don't enjoy the work or the job or the corporate BS. They plan on you quitting after one year, and just hiring a bunch of new naive young people. They prey on people getting burnt out, and fresh blood coming in. That is the wrong attitude for a corporation. They love young people who don't know that the job sucks yet. I was really upset when I realized they lied to me. They take you to hotel ballroom to train and really brainwash you that this is going to be the best experience of your life and I was too young to know any better. The job sucks. I would only recommend working there if you are 22 and need a computer and want to put Apple on your resume. Get out after a year. Seriously. for your mental health.
cons:
Work/Life balance was always a fight. stupid 8am meetings on sundays or trainings. they were always scheduling dumb brainwashing meetings. 
I was part time (full time will make you want to leave) and even at part time there were all these dumb requirements which you had to work certain days and times, even though there were 200 employees. 

i had eight managers. all of them telling me different things. way too many corporate speech. One time i was late due to a personal emergency and manager said "We need to protect our customer experience" and admonished me.

What about protecting your employee experience?

They were always trying to brainwash us to love apple. Pump up meeting with fake enthusiasm. the management invented a word "Grustle" which meant grind & hustle. 

The best managers were always the ones who were promoted within Apple. they understood what i was like to be an entry level employee.

Then they started outsourcing and bringing Managers in from Macy's and Sephora and Best Buy and they were always the worst. 

Apple pretends to "enrich the world" but at the end of the day it was about numbers and goals and selling their stupid applecare, which was usually never worth it.
Advice to Management
The Managers treat the employees like cogs. Some are cool. But most treated us like robots/vending machines for iphones. Only once or twice in four years did a manager ever ask me a question about what I do outside of work.

Act like you care (or do) about your employees. be a human. stop trying so hard to get promoted so you can have your own Apple store. That will come if you are just a great manager.

pros: As far as retail jobs go, this isn't the worst one out there. The pay is (or at least once was) competitive, and the company offers a lot of perks for workers, such as healthcare (even for some PT employees), a 401k, ongoing training and mentoring, tuition reimbursement, different avenues for specialization, etc. Several of my former coworkers went on to work for Apple corporate, usually at the encouragement of their managers who recognized their talent and interest in certain aspects of the business and helped them get to where they wanted to go.
cons:
The customers are either borderline-cultish Apple fans or completely unreasonable. Of course, there are those who fall in between, but those two groups were nightmares to deal with on a daily basis, especially in a fast-paced environment.

In my time there (about four years), the standards for hiring went from being highly selective to just needing bodies to fill the sales floor. The company was growing rapidly and the retail workforce was struggling to keep up with demand. Hiring sprees filled the stores with employees who likely would not have been hired back in the heyday of Apple retail, which seemed to make existing employees' jobs more difficult rather than less so.

With that, wages and salaries decreased, along with raises and promotions. At the same time, Apple was constantly in the news about how many billions of dollars they were making and then spending on this, that, and the other, yet the employees were seeing little of it.

Management also dwindled in quality, as those promoted into leadership positions were mediocre, at best.

review_title: It's impossible to connect the dots looking forward.
pros:
Apple will do absolute wonders to make you feel included, heard, and an important asset to your store's team. The culture, training, and opportunities that will be presented to you in a 2-4 year career in retail can rapidly accelerate you onwards and upwards.

I was lucky enough to be able to go on a career experience after two years in retail and it absolutely opened doors for me. If you can find a good team, with solid management -- the pay, benefits, and perks are awesome.
cons:
Retail management will often lose sight of the appeal of Apple, and what makes Apple, Apple. As with all performance-based roles, the tendency of management (especially with not a lot of Apple tenure) to lean into the numbers game can be frustrating.

Focus on providing a great service to your customers, and learn as much as you can. Don't let the managers get to you about scorecards and performance. Your actions and patience will absolutely be testing by the biggest Karen's known to man, but you can perservere.

Learn everything you can.
Be a sponge.
Springboard this opportunity into something big.

DON'T lean into work politics, drama, or the 'high-school' side of the store. (Often in lower volume stores...this is product zone.)
Be an expert, even in a entry-level position. Know your $H#t, do your work, don't stand around on your phone or gossip with your coworkers. Leaders will recognize this and move you fast. Show you're hungry, and you will go far.
Advice to Management
My store lost a lot of good people very rapidly due to poor management and a collapse on the original store culture I was hired with. Hang on to the good ones. My management failed to realize a lot of the aging (meaning older han 25) talent was preparing to jump ship and incentivized new and younger employees to fill gaps when they obviously weren't ready. This led to a complete collapse of people who took pride in their work and an influx of people who showed up for a paycheck and didn't take their work seriously. The quality of the store drastically dropped and our GM was noticably absent MONTHS out of the year, disappearing to Florida several times, seemingly completely out of the loop when returning to store, and their underlings were unprepared and unmotivated to step up to managing the store in her absence.

review_title: Mentally drained; a shy away from being a cult
pros:
- Great coworkers with amazing personalities
- Mostly everyone is willing to accept feedback to better themselves
- Being able to train others in topics you strive in
cons:
- Bad hours
- Biased management. If your views and goals don't match their financial agenda, you'll be "volentold" to develop yourself towards those goals. (they were always trade in related because it affects their bonus)
- Horrible pay (most raises for a $2T company showing 1-3% annually with them leading "this is all we could get you" while still being underpaid by more than 10% compared to others)
- Needed competitive salary, but they would never do it
- Customers belittle you almost as much as management at times
- Overworked; never given time to take a breather. If you aren't producing the numbers they want you to produce, they'll force you to "work" on it.
- Managers can care less about the best resolution for a customer and employee; will only give their opinion which is always to purchase a new computer because it affects their paychecks.
Advice to Management
Re-assess how you treat your employees. Most are not happy, even the people who "drink the Apple Juice". The direction of shoving products down people's throats (i.e. All in on iPhone) devalues the reputation we have with customers. Employees despise working on it, we're forced to adapt to new goals always centered around SELL, SELL, SELL, when realistically, we're no better than our competitors by doing so.

review_title: The Best Retail Job to Get
pros: Great health benefits. Great mental health support. Freebies. Great discounts on Apple Products and Third Party Accessories. The most diverse work environment. Staff members come from diverse ethnical backgrounds and ages. Work coaching. Career development plan. Continuous paid training time. Good break room. Culture of feedback.
cons:
Best internal work opportunities are given to expert workers or to anyone who is close friends with management team members. This stalls and frustrates employees with neutral friendship with lead team members. It's very difficult to over achieve work performance which stalls your annual raise. Some managers are in their position mainly because they've worked many years before in another retail store. Some managers are not people oriented as they favour employees they personally are friends with or hang out with. Your work experience and personal successes achieved outside Apple are not considered when applying for lead positions internally. Only internal work experience seems to count when applying for new work positions. Management team is almost fully caucasian. It's extremely rare to see a manager of colour (black, eastern Indian, Asian of colour, or Latino). Managers in most stores do not ethnically represent the diverse ethnical pool of employees working on the floor.
Advice to Management
Expert or pro employees already get paid well and have better benefits than most. Please offer new expert or lead opportunities to base level specialists so they can feel motivated and grow too.

Career opportunities are very rarely an option. You must do 3-4 years to even consider moving.

Everything is a secret, even the chip you are working on.. for 2 years I didn’t know what product I’m working on. Everyone in the floor kitchen is afraid to speak about what he does because this is the company culture.. again very unsociable habit.
Advice to Management
Promote social activity 
Get more involved in the tasks that you request. Or just take the engineer’s word..

pros: You get to meet customer’s from all over the world, and you also learn so much about technology. It’s also nice if your under 35 because everyone is around the age so you can easily make friends and meet some great people. Great enviornment to form connections with the variety of customers. You work with a diverse group of people compared to other places. Different people are good at different things. (Music, Art, Tech, etc) Apple discounts are nice, especially the $500 off with the 25% that you get every 2-3 years. It’s pretty easy to get time-off because there are so many employees and they weren’t super strict on call out’s. Also, weird fact. I noticed people had a cold in the store pretty often. I would assume this is because you are interacting with thousands of people a week. I got sick more working there than I ever had in my life.
cons:
Takes like 3-5 interviews to get hired. If you drink the Apple Kool-Aid you will be promoted. The politics are pretty horrible. The people who work hard don’t get promoted but the lazy ones do. It’s almost impossible to become full-time. Scheduling is pretty tough. You will always work weekends. It’s almost impossible not to because most times that is the busiest. The turn around rate is pretty high, new employees were coming in and out. This is managers included. They all quit and were replaced. There are high expectations and no bonuses considering you can make millions youself for the company in a year. The favorites move up and around more than others. Playing favorites is HEAVY.
Advice to Management
The best way to improve the culture at apple is to reward those who deserve it, and if you’re going to depend on certain employess, promote those people. Don’t exploit them.

pros:
If you are seeking to break into a well-known large corporation, starting as AHA (At Home Advisor) is a great way to get your foot in the door while you figure out what you want to do career-wise. 

Partner Relations Advisor supposed to be a B to B client management role, however, this truly is a call center job. 

Internal movement is very limited for AHA employees not resides near actual corporate functions offices. 

Overall I gained valuable lessons and was satisfied with pay/benefit for what the job was. Left the company for better opportunity.

Pros:
- Pay was above average for call center type settings
- You can put Apple on your resume
- You can familiarize yourself with OS system
- Internal opportunities (Rotations, career exchange, etc)



If you enjoy heavily metric driven and process oriented environment, go for it! At the end of the day, Apple is Apple. Great way to start building your career.
cons:
Cons:
- Limited internal opportunities if you don't live near Apple offices
- AHA really isn't a long term career
- No holidays
- Call center = angry clients
- Metric driven: Average call time, email time, contents, calls are all monitored and measured at all times
- Supervisor will critique your calls and emails randomly 3-4 times /month and you get rated
Advice to Management
AHA career opportunities were so limited for remote workers

review_title: Marketing/Marcom...It's Gonna Be a No From Me Dawg!
pros: Looks good on your resume, mostly kind and smart peers, learning about new products before the rest of the world, brand new MacBook Pro, team diversity
cons:
Where to begin...There are 2345253 people working on 3 projects. Everything is slow, there is no innovation and when you do work on cool projects, they get cancelled at the last minute. Leadership is lacking in Marcom. I had such high hopes of working here but was so let down by the culture and leadership. Marcom leadership doesn't know what they're doing and maybe that's because they don't have to? What makes Apple special is their design and products, not the marketing. Inexperienced leadership was the biggest letdown. I'm sure they are trying their best but it's amateur hour and to top it off they're not very welcoming to new team members. I'm glad I took the job and have it on my resume, but I don't think I would recommend working here in marketing to an enemy.
Advice to Management
Everything you're doing in Marcom is not working. Go through some leadership training! You really need it! Acknowledge new team members, build a culture so people stop jumping ship. Listen! Ask questions! Try!

pros:
- Unparalleled benefits, especially for Healthcare and opportunity for equity ownership
- Not beholden to quotas, and goals created in partnership with corporate guidance
- Highest level of job security
- Tons of self-guided training
- Lots of people to constantly connect with, all spanning rich, diverse cultures and backgrounds in entry to senior level customer-facing roles
cons:
- limited opportunity for growth in same field of work unless willing to relocate
- cash compensation is on very low side of being competitive
- no quotas gives perception that micromanagement is needed to achieve goals
- very limited number of other folks in same department in immediate vicinity, leading to a lack of empathy for the role's responsibilities
- Extremely disjointed leadership teams spanning multiple different departments, leading to an "Office Space" situation of reporting to 15 different bosses
- Lack of diversity in leadership
Advice to Management
Centralize business teams in miniature call centers in key markets throughout region, and consolidate Business Pro roles to those mini-call centers. Continue to use Business Experts in the store to qualify leads, engage with sales floor and Genius Bar, and train folks in an Experience.

pros:
If I'd could, I'd rate Apple 3.5 stars. 

• Great benefits & healthcare. 
• College students are given more room to make mistakes, but the expectation is that even college students should eventually perform on the same level as regular employees
• Team Managers are deeply invested in helping struggling employees become better at their roles
• Apple generally wants all employees to feel as if they have autonomy within the company; many opportunities to offer feedback on company tools
• Senior Leaders is accessible to basic employees
• Good discounts on Apple Product & services
• AppleCare College specifically gives students the ability to schedule around their classes

Not-pros-but-not-cons

Generally inclusive environment (but it's only the best you can hope for in corporate America, as a transgender employee I was often left having to explain my struggles to people who didn't really act upon anything beyond saying "check our benefits").

Apple offers 'rotations' to other corporate positions, which let employees in one role temporarily migrate to another branch of the company to learn new skills & see another side of the business. From all the rotations I was offered, strangely, I was offered a rotation to "Tier 2 AppleCare". While it was functionally another side of the business, it was really the same as my Tier 1 role with more responsibility, pressure, & room for failure. There was no pay-raise, no promise of promotion, beyond that "it will look great on a resume". I don't regret taking the Tier 2 position, but I wish there was better compensation than promises.

AppleCare is a demanding job. You're not just troubleshooting software & hardware, you're quite literally trying to solve people's perceived emotional problems with their technology. Apple is invested in ensuring customers feel that their technology isn't a problem, & sometimes you're having to de-escalate emotional issues. Some customers make this challenging.

Performance metrics are micromanaged, but certain metrics matter more than others. Most Team Managers I had assessed me on my own merits, quirks, & shortcomings, but each manager had different points of concern.
cons:
• Non-stop work, draining & hard to remain at peak performance through long shifts
• Work is super challenging, lots to internalize, learn, remember, & actively use. You cannot coast through this job
• Easy to get lost & forgotten among the thousands of employees
• Limited career advancement from within AppleCare
• Networking opportunities are extremely difficult, as there are limited chances to really speak to coworkers
• At-home work environment can be incredibly isolating

Maybe it was my College position, but advancing the ranks within Apple seemed labyrinthine, & I wasn't ever able to get clear answers on how advancement worked. I was generally an average employee, with middle-of-the road stats. I imagined if I tried harder, I could get a generally idea of how advancing to leadership positions within AppleCare or Apple Corporate worked, but that nobody really bothered to tell me in my 4 years made me feel small & forgotten. I was also so absorbed in school that I imagine Apple reserved advancement opportunities for regular employees.

Apple partners with a 3rd party company to help provide college tuition reimbursement, but from 2017-2021 it required students to make B's or higher in their courses. I was never able to make these goals, as it was my fault. I lost access to the key to making college manageable for me.
Advice to Management
If there is any way to make from-home work environments more social, please do so. This job is isolating

review_title: Apple retail is great stepping stone or in-between, but can be a dead end for long-term career growth.
pros: Better hourly pay when compared to most retail jobs. Medical, dental, and vision coverage available even to part-time employees. Other perks like employee discounts, commuter benefits, fitness reimbursement, and some mental health support coverage. Usually good diversity amongst staff and leadership. Great place to develop customer service and basic technical troubleshooting skills.
cons:
Considering it's a trillion dollar company, they still undervalue most retail employees. If you don't want to become a manager, paths for upward mobility in retail are limited and even the more senior roles for sales, tech support, operations, and other teams are underpaid. There are a lot of metrics and sometimes unrealistic goals set as performance indicators. In other words, when you try to emphasize everything as important, then nothing is important.
Advice to Management
Pay retail employees more. So many things are good or almost good about working at Apple, but I think retention would be higher if people felt like they could sustain themselves long-term working on the retail side. Hire more managers, leadership is usually trying their best, but they are spread too thin to truly support staff in most stores and keep up with the seemingly endless priorities corporate sets for us. Let part-timers accumulate PTO. Everyone deserves time off without stressing about their bills. Use our money and influence to truly be about our values and not just at the surface level.

pros:
Although a sometimes frantic work environment, Apple developed me professionally, and re-set my expectations for what I was capable of in a business environment. I met and worked for some of the best humans i've ever met- and will always be thankful for that....although I know everyone is not so lucky- the company generally attracts great talent. 
The perfect job for younger aged people looking to develop leadership and business skills. Also great for retired-aged employees looking for a great social environment.
Pay is the most competitive you will find in a retail environment. Benefits are solid, and stock options are widely available and generally included in all offers.
cons:
Some dangling of the carrot, some repetitive daily/Weekly/quarterly mechanisms with minimal benefit long term. On the tech side- the Genius role is a ceiling I hit, with only Management roles opening up after. After 5 years, I jumped to a corporate position elsewhere to explore further career and development goals as well as higher pay tiers.
Advice to Management
Constantly develop, inspire and laugh with your staff!

pros: The People. Your Apple coworkers become your family, and this is one of the top reasons why people stay so long. (Speaking specifically to the retail environment)
cons:
Dealing with ambiguity is a skill that most successful Apple employees have, but too much ambiguity leads to a level of dissatisfaction when it comes to knowing what’s next regarding development and job opportunities. Communication amongst and from leadership could be improved. It is a sad reality that there is little diversity in management across all of Apple. The company is definitely trying to make some changes in their approach to hiring inclusively, but there is so much unconscious and implicit bias to work through that this may take another 5–10 years for real change to happen from entry level to executive roles.
Advice to Management
Have more transparent, honest, and clearly communicated conversations with your team members. Try to check your biases regularly.

pros: Apple is a great company to want to work for! It thrives in innovation and the discounts provided, you cannot beat. The way Apple trains you is top tier. I've taken what I've learned at Apple in other job roles. They really do care about their customers and finding the best solutions for them.
cons:
Moving up is hard, especially in retail. In my store, the people that were mostly promoted were "yes man" or people with little to no opinion. Also, few minorities were promoted. I've been told by mgmt time and time again it's a game. You have to play the game. No work environment should be like that. Time off is a whole other topic. Mgmt would be passive-aggressive when it came to you needing time off or in my experience, I was in school too. Managing work and school balance sometimes my mental would suffer and instead of being understanding, Mgmt would try and make you feel bad. Raises? Good Luck! Quarter raises would be maybe an extra dollar or two and they would expect you to be so excited! Wow, a whole $1.30 after 4 years and exceeding expectations. I mean, if you can look past all these factors, you will enjoy your experience.
Advice to Management
Having round tables with stores would be great and allow your team to express real concerns! My store leader provided that and although no real change happened, the thought of other stores following suit could really provide change with those conversations being documented and given to corporate. If patterns are found in other stores then maybe real change can occur. Create a safe space for your minorities. It's a lack in that department.

review_title: Good but not a long term career unless you’re okay with very slow career growth
pros:
For some background: I started in the college program working part-time as an Mac+ Advisor for 2.5 years. After graduating, I was offered a full-time position and immediately promoted to iOS Senior Advisor role. I worked as an iOS Senior Advisor for 2 years. I had the opportunity to temporarily be a Mac+ mentor for newly trained advisors making their first every calls with customers and work in a retail store repairing iOS devices. Right before I was about to leave the company, I was offered to laterally move to Mac+ Senior Advisor. I consistently ranked top 5%-10% in average metrics amongst all company-wide Advisors.

The pay was good for what the job entailed when comparing to other companies.

You get a wide variety of customers, making it pretty interesting day-to-day.

I definitely learned how to be patient with people and how to keep your cool even if someone is berating you.

Apple definitely sets you up for success when it comes to providing you the resources to perform your job properly. There’d be some situations where there wasn’t actually any documented process for certain situations, but I can’t blame the company for that since those situations were fairly rare.
cons:
During my time with the company, it was clear that as internal advisors were leaving, the company was filling those positions with contractors. These contractors usually never really actually fixed issues properly and that would cause customers to repeatedly call back for same issues. What this meant to me is that Senior Advisors were primarily there to clean up contractors’ mistakes and “win” the customer back.

Frequent management and team changes happened every year, sometimes even multiple times a year for some. This made it difficult to make any lasting relationships with co-workers as well as when it was already difficult to do so in a remote setting. I had 5 different managers with 4 completely different teams within a 4.5 year span. 

Most managers were not very technical and when they review your performance, they mostly look at the metrics and how much you contributed to the company as a whole (kind of hard when the manager has only worked with you for a year or less).

Once you get to Senior Advisor role, it’s fairly clear that if you want to promote to anything else, you have to drink the Apple Juice and be a “puppet” for management for a few years. Even then, chances are very minimal as the competition is extremely high regardless of how consistently high your annual review/metrics are.

In the end, this is a customer service job, not a technical job. I’m definitely a more technical person and regardless of how technical you are and how well you are at resolving issues, management won’t recognize it since you ultimately are just number for them amongst a huge pool of customer service employees. Yes, Apple provides possible paths to a more technical position within AppleCare, but even then, it is very difficult to get there with opportunities being limited. The ones that got there in the first place after starting as an advisor were with the company for more than 6-8 years back when the company wasn’t as large as it is today. Once I realized this, I didn’t want to spend most of my young career years trying to get noticed at a lower level position of a major tech company.

review_title: Stable place to grow your skills
pros: Opportunities for technical certifications, valuable customer service skills are gained, very stable employment. Overall can be a great place to build skills. Excellent benefits.
cons:
Functional technical experience can be very limited. Training quality is not as high as in prior years. Annual/cost of living increases are low and eventually a technician’s skill set and gained experience makes them more valuable than the company will acknowledge. Not a place to have a true career. Management quality varies dramatically and your direct manager will change frequently. Hours are rough, and you will sometimes feel overworked.
Advice to Management
The really effective and supportive managers do not always rise to the top; listen to employees when they tell you who those managers are and actively try to learn from them. It makes an enormous difference. Find and address the staff that create negative energy among their peers, one person can break down the culture of an entire team. Encourage burnt out employees by finding an area where their skills can still grow and letting them spend part of their time doing that - attitudes and productivity will improve.

pros: Incredible job while in college, relatively good pay, benefits are nice (Stock, 401k, discounts). You are able to learn and grow a lot in this type of role.
cons:
Management, at least at my store, are obsessive about metrics and prioritize AppleCare and activations over the customer's experience. They also recognize people who painting strong metric even if those employees are not transparent with customer. Very used car salesperson like.

Management can be very demanding when it comes to availability. The have had a hard time understand the workload college can bring and at times are not very accommodating with scheduled hours. They will try to work you as much as they can, even if it becomes unhealthy for you.
Advice to Management
Treat everyone equal and don't play favorites. It is almost impossible to move into a new role unless you kiss up to a manager at this store. Stop overworking employees and respect that they have other commitments like school and family. Make up your mind, are we here to help people or sell warranties? You can't preach both narratives and expect us to feel motivated or inspired.

pros: Great benefits package overall. Great gym, amazing canteen! The stock plan is well organised and it is a good way to invest in the company.
cons:
I am an Apple employee in Cork and I would suggest you to think twice before accepting a job in Apple Hollyhill. 

*Management*
I have to say that I have never seen such poor management. People with no merit and no qualifications are managers in finance, apple care etc...I have seen 20 year-old people becoming manager after few years of work, no school, no real experience... It is the perfect place for mediocrity!!

*Employees care*
Funny story.. Apple is making a huge amount of money during pandemic, we as employees got a 15€ taxi voucher as a Christmas "present" and as a thanks for our hard work during the pandemic. This is ridiculous!! 

*Work/Life Balance*
Managers (apart from AppleCare) do not respect your personal life. I have been asked why was I out sick when I took 1 day off because of my personal issues. I have been asked to log into the system and work during my Christmas holidays. 

*Inequalities*
Apple is claiming to be the perfect place to work for inclusion and diversity but the truth is that Apple is discriminating a lot. People from different departments get different benefits, for example during Covid people in AppleCare got their internet reimbursed 50€/month, but in my team (finance) we didn't get anything, 0€!! When I asked if I could go back to my home country during Covid I was told that just higher managers could do it, the rest of us has to stay in Cork and pay incredibly expensive rents and sit in house arrest.

review_title: The store I worked at was terrible, but is not a reflection on Apple Retail as a whole.
pros:
Excellent benefits system.
The kit you use and internal systems are very slick.
cons:
Awful for work/life balance. You can start at 7:30am, and finish at 8-9pm in a 9 hour shift somewhere in that. Those days are complete write-offs.
Generally terrible management - a bunch of ex-clothes retail and hospitality people. Prejudice, favouritism, unfair treatment, open bias, leaders that stand around brazenly doing nothing on their phones, poor recognition and development of skilled people that care, bullying - basically all the things you can think of that are the last you would want leadership to be.
A toxic environment breeding negativity and apathy toward the job.
Advice to Management
Stop treating passion as negativity. You will only make these jewel employees negative and apathetic toward their duties.
Work hard at identifying the people that want to be there and champion them. You have a responsibility to look after your team, and they will look after you.
Stop promoting your favourites, and give people equal opportunities.
Be fair when dealing with disciplinaries.
Be respectful of customers - remember that employees will just mirror your behaviour.
Be respectful of your employees, and they will respect you.
Be grateful you've got it easy compared to other industries, and respect the job accordingly.
Stop having favourites.
Stop celebrating revenue. You're not kidding anyone. Find ways that the team can improve their skills and celebrate that instead.
Learn what your teams are doing in their jobs, instead of assuming they're doing nothing. Maybe you will then be in a position to tell them what to do without upsetting them.

review_title: Fun place to work for the most part, but don’t expect to go far.
pros: Great people to work with, good team support, and often times fun.
cons:
Biased leadership, favoritism when it comes to advancement, some decisions just makes no sense, and as far as the customers go they can often be annoyingly (and stupidly) entitled.
Advice to Management
This review is about Apple Retail. It is a fun culture to be a part of, and a great way to learn most of the ins and outs of customer service, whether you’re selling stuff or repairing stuff. However, if you’re looking for either horizontal or vertical advancement opportunities, know this: Apple Retail is indisputably a clique. Despite what the company claims, Apple Retail leadership is generally biased and whether it takes you 3 months or a year, you will eventually realize that opportunities are given mostly based on favoritism that is sometimes thinly and other times heavily disguised by a very strenuous interview process during which you are forced to go through 3, 4 or more interviews and you will usually be turned down the first time you apply for a new position (sometimes without even any constructive feedback to go off of to improve yourself for future interview processes). Personally, I started my 3-year journey with Apple Retail very enthusiastically and successfully by any measure (bonuses, MVP status, positive leadership feedback, etc.) and unfortunately ended my employment there on a very bitter note. Best of luck to you, but heed my words because they are very solid and easy to prove.

Get everyone in leadership on the same page, walk the talk of the creedo and stop being so pretentious in hiding behind the so-called “Apple juice”. Generally, just try and be more genuine and fair, it isn’t as hard as you think, and most employees would appreciate you more.

review_title: Fake Promotions, Department Mergers, and Bad Management
pros: Apple seemed like a dream when I arrived. It was peak iPhone and the company was growing rapidly. The stock was doing well, it seemed like there was a lot of possibility to move up, and people generally had a positive attitude. New buildings were beautiful and the food was cheap and tasty.
cons:
There was a dark side. The food got more expensive and to order it, you had to install a profile that gave Apple full access to your iPhone. Fake promotions, bad managers, rotations or "career experiences" for what should have been actual positions (all about saving money). Apple is good at making profit off their own employees. Product discounts were the same as educators, 25% is not great. Also, I knew 3 people who committed suicide and one guy who became jaundiced and stopped coming to work because he died. The worst part was the cold response from management. Also if you get one of those "fake promotions," know that HR definitely does not have your back. A manager can actually tell you to your face during an internal interview that a position is a promotion with a raise, but then you make the move and find out it's lateral and there's no consequence for the manager who baited you with the false promise. These sorts of practices were quite common for me and others and it seemed most were happy to put up with it because it was Apple and they didn't know better. Always ask the position and number when you interview, get as much in writing as possible, and realize that a positive performance review will not equate to an increase in pay despite the company's cash situation. The kool-aid is strong here, so keep things in perspective. You are a number. You are disposable. If you give 2 weeks notice, that's actually your final day.
Advice to Management
Stop treating your employees like children.

review_title: Impossible Expectations, High Stress, Hostile Colleagues
pros:
- Decent pay and bonus, but not competitive with the market when breaking it down by the hour
-cool campus,
- you will learn a lot, although it is not worth the sacrifices you will make
cons:
Apple is undoubtedly one of the most innovative companies on the tech hardware market today, but what people don’t realize is what employees of Apple sacrifice in order to obtain this innovation for the company. While many departments within Apple have a good work life balance and receive compliments from management, the supply chain and purchasing department of Apple is the complete opposite. Supply chain is one of Apple’s largest competitive advantages, and you will feel the pain and burden of that every moment of every day.

The Global Supply Manager role is incredibly demanding. My day would typically start at 9:00 AM, and end around 11:00 PM, and there were multiple times that I would have calls at 2:30 AM. My management knew my hours and my stress, and instead of helping lighten the workload, they told me to, “stay optimistic”, and then several weeks later they doubled my scope of responsibilities. You will have colleagues texting you and calling you at 11:00 PM on weekdays and weekends. The only way to escape this invasive behavior is to place your phone on airplane mode, although you will get in trouble for this when you fail to answer a single text or phone call.

There are not enough hours in the day to get everything done, even if you are a Type A person who is extremely organized and productive. I should clarify that the hours are not the worst part of the job, instead, it is your colleagues who are just as nervous, tired, stressed, and angry at everything as you are. Apple encourages a very hostile environment, both internally and externally, where Global Supply Managers are encouraged to have extremely aggressive discussions with suppliers and individuals from other departments. There is no problem at Apple that cannot be solved by yelling and using condescending language. I have seen Apple employees yell at people earning a tenth of what they earn half way across the globe for problems that individual had no way of controlling. I’ve been in procurement for some time, and I have never seen people treated in such an undignified way as Apple supply chain professionals treat their suppliers and colleagues.

There is no balance in work life. If you have children or a spouse, then those relationships must be de-prioritized in place of Apple. At the end of the day, Apple will chew you up and spit you out, because no matter how loudly you voice that the expectations are not sustainable, they know that there are 30 more applicants fresh out of college who will take your place and be willing to do so for less pay. These fresh faces will then last one or two years, only to then be replaced. It is an endless cycle, and this is nothing new for Apple. Perspective employee beware. When applying for Apple, I remember reading negative reviews such as this one, and quickly disregarding them because I labeled those reviews as “overly-dramatic”, but after two weeks at Apple, I realized how true the other cautionary reviews on this website were.
Advice to Management
Hire the correct number of employees to handle the expectations set.

pros: Great entry point into IT, lots to learn and develop if you're willing to put in the work and more importantly, vocal about it
cons:
Apple is a corporate office in a retail space and it definitely operates more like corporate office. Performance metrics are confusing and sometimes difficult to quantify, can feel useless at times when it comes to overall performance. Development paths are ambiguous, everyone recommends something different. 

Work Life balance isn't always the best 

Leadership is notoriously aloof, you'll need to campaign like a politician to get what you want. 

Because development is disjointed, colleague interactions can often feel artificial and micromanage-y if either parties are trying to develop skills/move up.

review_title: Amazing Company / Amazing Values / Poor Internal Execution
pros: Best products in the world hands down! Benefits are out of this world and definitely the only reason I'm still with the company. Basically impossible to be fired.
cons:
Basically impossible to be fired, however, they can and will leave you in the same position with a 1% to 2% annual raise. You are easily forgotten as an individual all in the name of the company's lofty goals. If you are not an exempt salaried employee, then you can basically expect to only take advantage of a fraction of the real benefits. Finally, unless you are an extremely unique minority outlier you will have an extraordinarily difficult time gaining opportunities for advancement.
Advice to Management
Hire from within. Stop spending so much time on Diversity and Inclusion (Diversionary and segregation) Hire based on merit only!

pros: Good perks like healthcare for being in Ireland, the job itself is easy enough
cons:
I feel like a number. Nothing more. All of us have been working from home and instead of valuing that financially, we get a free box of nuts and potato crisps now and then. 
The employee support is useless. I haven’t the slightest clue why there are ways to contact them if nothing ever happens.
Apple claims to be a tolerant and open minded company and - while App Review is absolutely the one place we can say that feels like a fun place to work, I’ve collected many stories from colleagues about previous experiences. 
There is bullying in Apple. There is just no one in Apple to help you when it happens to you. 
One of my ex-colleagues was bullied by her manager who then made sure that when for organisational reasons the entire team went to someone else, she wouldn’t get a new manager. That colleague reported this several times and only after she left the company, they made sure to ask to not look like a bad employer.
I myself have reported abuse and nothing happened. 
I entered Apple with high hopes and job-wise I am good. But on a human level Apple is an enabler for abusive behaviour.
Advice to Management
Change the employee support system. I am just one of many people who you have failed. Many of them have left while their bullies remain. I haven’t left yet, but am looking. I wouldn’t recommend working with Apple to anyone. And I’ve even switched away from Apple products personally because it all feels like a lie by now.
