pros:
Relatively good stock options (RSU, given annually).
Free food on shift from time to time and other small perks.
Very talented and amicable team of colleagues. Managerial staff very understanding, reasonable and helpful.
Most important: Looks good on a CV.
cons:
All of these are core issues which are company-specific and do not in any way relate to the genuinely fantastic team of people who work in the retail stores.
Incredible amounts of stress/ being overworked. Throughout my time there, less and less freedom and trust was afforded to us in the way that we worked, often forcing us to not be able to present adequate solutions to customers, and indeed often forcing us to say things to the customer that we didn't agree with and which were totally unreasonable.
Gym and dental reimbursements simply not accepted despite constant emails to HR (I tried for 6 months to get these through HR and I left the company and never received these. £650 out of pocket).
Most of the workforce is talented and capable of getting a higher paid job elsewhere rather than being stuck in retail and being overworked, but Apple ties you into its ecosystem. Whilst the RSUs are very much welcome, these vest over three years and are therefore another way in which many amongst the workforce are essentially trapped.
Most of the workforce who want to progress internally are put in makeshift 'career experience' roles which second them to another position and give them the sense of progression without the physical achievement, doing a higher-paid job for no change in salary. In the event that the opportunity to progress is achieved, it often means relocating elsewhere in the country to another store.
Brainwashing of staff to follow a 'credo' (I didn't subscribe to the 'brainwashing' narrative initially, however it took some time to snap out of it before realising that Apple does much to suck you, as an employee, into its ecosystem and to get you to subscribe to its agenda). In relation, on occasion some very political issues were forced onto staff from higher up via internal channels, in so much as that not having a certain opinion on a certain topic is unacceptable.
Advice to Management
Decrease the workload on individual employees; despite being at the recommended amount of people (which management kept repeating to us), more people certainly needed to be hired (this is genius-bar specific, perhaps not necessarily on red zone/ product zone staff). Otherwise, whilst managerial behaviour is most often impeccable and reasonable, in general please be more pragmatic and human with the staff regarding the credo etc. Reiterating this is simply patronising and only inspires the small minority of employees whose freedom of thought has already been hijacked by the way that the suits in Cupertino want employees to think.

pros:
Company has very high ethical standards and wants to be fair.
Very smart, capable experts in their fields
cons:
antly striving for perfection
Good pay and benefits
Cons
Decisions are made in Cupertino by the exec team, and the rest of the org works internally to influence decisions upward and then executes against those plans after approved. It can become frustrating if you are used to making decisions.
Career mobility is extremely limited (no horizontal, some promotions but in title only). Most people stay in the same job for 8-10 years. It can harm you when you leave the company to go somewhere else. Your perspective is very narrow.
Spend most of your time on internal communications and influencing.
Advice to Management
Find ways to eliminate the extremely slow decision making processes in middle management.

pros: A refreshingly collaborative environment that lends itself to personal growth and development. There is a stringent hiring process, but it ultimately results in the organization sourcing candidates that are like-minded, empathetic, and forming connections is generally pretty easy.
cons:
Growth opportunities are limited and ultimately a byproduct of favoritism rather than any real sense of objectivity and what is sensible for the team. Within the last month, the interview process has been moderately altered and offers more of a sense of objectivity, but is ultimately farcical. Initiatives at the retail level ultimately revolve around meeting the demand of unreliable performance metrics and wildly varying company directives. The organization also lays claim to compassion and direct action toward protecting human rights without recognition to its own transgressions against humanity, utilizing slave / internment labor to fulfill manufacturing in China, compliance with initiatives which stand directly against any modicum of humanity. Between the stockpile of cash reserves, the year over year growth in valuation and earnings, one would think that they would pay their employees more fairly, but that's also tossed to the wayside. There is not any shred of real accountability or integrity within the confines of this place, and anyone who states otherwise is participating in and complicit with the facade.
Advice to Management
The majority of the management I've encountered offer very little in regard to genuine growth or development, have an underwhelming amount of technical knowledge, and often are not fit to be in positions of leadership. There's also a robotic nature to all of them where they've mastered the art of appearing to care, but ultimately offer nothing of real support or benefit in extenuating circumstances or accommodating genuine need.

review_title: Good first job with benefits. Don't stay longer than a few years though.
pros: Good benefits for a first job/ college job
cons:
To get promoted you have to do more than just have excellent numbers. You have to come up with all sorts of useless extra charts, mass emails to the team on best practices, memos, side projects etc that make it *look* like you're going above and beyond or "innovating" as they call it. Really no one reads any of it and it's completely useless for anything other than your ability to make an argument for promotion when the time comes. The company says this is to drive innovation from the bottom, but really that only comes from management and they disregard any feedback on meaningful changes. It feels like all management does is discuss how to generate "buy-in" as they call it from the team on what ever the companies flavor of the month is in terms of what ever metric they'd like to track. The company repeats over and over that "It's not about the metics or numbers" and "it's about enriching lives" when in reality it is very much all about the numbers, but they frame it in this very Orwellian way where instead of saying "your numbers for applecard financing are low" they'll say something like "We know that talking about Apple Card and teaching customers about its benefits gives customers another incredible option to bring home this amazing technology today that will enrich their life". If you don't catch the hint that what they're saying is your numbers are low than you'll never get promoted, and you'll never get higher than average on a yearly review.

Then the biggest con- a different schedule every single day. You'll never have two days off together again.
Advice to Management
Instead of just generating a bunch of useless internal memos to "innovate" try actually looking at what numbers need work- then tell the employees the truth about it. Have them reverse shadow someone who excels in that, and then bring the whole team up together instead of being so obsessed with how to word things in the perfect way that inevitably leaves goals ambiguous at best, or dishonest at worst.

review_title: Center of Corruption, Racism, Sexism and Nepotism
pros: Salary is good and nothing else is good and that "nothing else" is not something bearable that you can say "okay I will try my best and I will save some money and I will leave". No sir, the cake's not worth the candle, really.
cons:
If you are not from some "certain" countries, you are on your own and nobody will care about you, nobody will help you when you need. And when it is time to give permanent Apple positions to the contractors, it is the worst part: if you are not boyfriend/girlfriend of "somebody who knows somebody" then you stand almost zero chance: they will give these permanent Apple positions as if they grant their own property to the people which they like. Nothing is about being qualified or how you do your job. For example, when I first applied for a permanent Apple position they said I didn't have enough experience which was 6 months, but they hired many many people with less than 2 months experience with nothing on their CV. Yes I asked them about it, how these guys had more experience than I did, they had no answer. Also some superior managers never introduce you to HQ in Cupertino. It is like a Sindrella story they want to hide you from the superior managements because maybe they might hire you and in that case these corrupted managers cannot give the position to their favored friends/partners. In my example, all the people who were given the permanent position were interviewed by my organization first and then by US organization. However I was interviewed first by managers of my team and the second interview was by the managers of my team once again. They didn't follow the usual interviewing procedures because they already decided about me months before the interview and if you pass their first interview, they organize a second one with irrelevant questions. Here, you might think that "okay dude obviously they were not happy with your service, the way you work" etc... No. A big NO as I have personally requested feedbacks all the time just to see if there was something negative so I'd be able to improve myself. I haven't had any negative feedback from any manager. On the contrary all the other leads and supervisors were telling me I was doing a great job and they used to thank me in person thanks to the way I do cooperate with them. Some of my supervisors were also surprised and upset when they heard the news that Apple didn't give me the permanent position and also they didn't extend my contract. Without any negative feedback, any explanation, any complaint... 
I was suspecting this kind of corruptions and I informed superior managers: "big guys", including my manager up to the highest level of the management I also tried to get help from "Business Conduct" and they also ignored this corruption. (Business conduct is supposed to deal with any kind of misconduct so here nepotism, racism and sexism are all "core values" of Apple, otherwise "Business Conduct" would take some action, no?) And these days I know they need to fill the position I left, I hear they interview some other people to hire as contractor/summer cover and guess what: most of the candidates are friends of the same "somebody". 
Ah I forgot the best part: 
when they didn't extend my contract, my team had a summer cover which barely had 10% of my experience and skills, they gave the position to her (because somebody in my team didn't like our team is "all male" so they wanted a "female") and they hired a friend of theirs who would also ignore their incompetent practices. So I have worked in/ for many international companies but Apple was the worst, a total career terrorism. They commit all the unprofessional and corrupted actions and they get away with it. I first thought it was just some corrupted people at Apple and the company would not tolerate any of it as they claim it with fancy words on twitter but I can say they just claim they are against racism, sexism, nepotism etc on social media but they promote all of these.
If you think Apple would be a career leap, remember about this message. If you are just a random person and cannot be favored by somebody in the management stay away. If you already have your own routine, if you are happy what you have now, do not take any risks with Apple because you might lose even what you have now.
In conclusion: There are many other details I forgot and I cannot put in here but I can say I thought I was the only one to be exposed all these misconducts but when I put the stick into the hornets' nest, I have seen there are way too many people suffered of the same thing. They are all from the different departments of the company in different countries. 
PS. I haven't mentioned how these new but favored people are awarded with test lead positions or some other managing roles while the other people who has been in the company since years (like 10+ years) were not promoted. It is not that only 1-2 bad apples corrupting the whole basket, no. All levels of the management are aware of the situation and they want to benefit from it. This is what they want.
Advice to Management
Do something about racism, sexism, nepotism in the company and run some mental checks on a regular basis especially on the managers. IT jobs require a sane mind and dealing with IT related stuff might have some bad effects on our mental health which is not the end of the world but please provide these ill-minded people with the required treatment otherwise they become dengerous lunatics destroying people's lives and careers.

pros: The benefits are quite good, you get nice discounts to buy some Apple products and you get an iPod Touch for free to use (you have to return it if you leave the company tho). The campus in Hollyhill, Cork is pretty cool, and the food is also nice
cons:
If you're hired as a Technical advisor, you're gonna have it really hard to leave AppleCare. During the interview process, I was told that after a year I could apply to a job outside AppleCare (I wanted to work in the marketing department or video production), but after 8 months, I had a meeting with my current manager and he told me that if I was hired to work in AppleCare I had to stay in AppleCare. He clearly was cutting down all my chances to change department, since to apply for another job I first need my manager approval. 
I was extremely disappointed so I decided to quit.
The work hours are extremely long. You technically have a 15 minutes break every 2h, but sometimes a call takes more than 2h and then you can't take the break. 
Also, if your launch break is after 2.30pm, and you didn't bring food with you, you won't eat anything because the dinning hall on campus is closed, which I find unacceptable since they know people have launch breaks after 3pm or even 5pm. 
You need to go to get your food during an early break (if you're not in the middle of a call) and get your food, but by the time you are on your launch break, the food is completely cold.
Advice to Management
Listen to the employees and make them feel like they are valuable

pros:
-tuition reimbursement is substantial 
-potential to do a career experience in corporate
-the best coworkers of all time 
-leadership that cares (for the most part) 
-free weekly covid tests sent to my house 
-401k match 100% up to 6% of your paycheck after 5 years. 
-great discounts on hero products 
-free Apple Music, iCloud storage (200GB), Games, and Apple TV 
-understanding leadership who gives you so many chances especially if you’ve been at the company for a while and you work hard. 
-$100 a month for commute 
-reallllyyy good health insurance. I can see my dentist for a cleaning 4 times a year if I want 
-lots of resources for learning through Apple
cons:
-way too much white leadership. 
-way too few women in leadership and technical roles. 
-lots of white men in leadership promoting other white men to leadership, over and over. 
-leadership should take into account the opinion of a coworkers peers before making decisions on promotions.
Advice to Management
Take notice of the people who are really trying their best and working hard. Take notice of which employees are truly liked and which aren’t. Employees who are liked by their peers and work hard get overlooked a lot because leadership is often distracted by employees who appear to have a very ‘high’ performance by numbers, and very, very poor relationships with their peers and with their customers.

pros:
- OK pay
- great name on a resume
- nice people
- easier to get into as temp winter employee
- stock is great, especially since they keep it affordable for entry level employees
- ok health unless your full time
cons:
- you must be a super energetic cheer leader for Apple to advance
- above requirement makes group think a big issue; hard to find original ideas
- sensitive; every day I work in fear because I never know what new extreme left policy they utilize will trigger false accusations 
- the need to appease identitarian extremists is so great I am regularly and falsely accused of discrimination
- huge lack of diversity. Everyone looks different, but thinks the same. It is kind of like the stepford wives. Lots of smiles and niceness, just don’t mention anything politically moderate or right leaning.
- because of all of the above, it isn’t uncommon to see employees emotionally and verbally abuse other employees for taking a stand for something that doesn’t align with identitarian intersectional ideology.
Advice to Management
Create a DNA for conservatives. Apple says they are “for everybody” in their values but fail miserably for people who are more conservative leaning. There have been so many people I’ve known who would say, “I am just using this place” or “this place will never accept me.” Lots of talent is lost in this manner, and having people who have been successful yet conservative at Apple guide you through understanding and navigating the terrain will help keep some talent. Though, because of the above cons, I seriously doubt Apple could find any leaders who are either conservative or will admit to being so.

pros: Benefits, sales experience, tech experience, discounts, small sample of leading corporate culture, great staff to work with. My immediate reporting manager was amazing as was my store manager/HR. Most of the time sales were easy.
cons:
INADEQUATE TRAINING. I was someone who started without an abundance of tech knowledge. My team taught me something new every day, all day. Normally a good thing but not great when the store is swamped (which frequently happens) and you're essentially on your own. Still retail, Same challenges with any other retail position: Unrealistic hours (cant exactly be helped. Weekends and nights), Not enough Pay to scrape by (On the higher side of retail though.) "Unspoken" sales/business intro/apple accessory + service quotas. Zero incentive to achieve a top position in any previously mentioned categories, aside from recognition. Any advancement WILL require some outside education. Apple/ Store sponsorship does exist to some varying degree. Apple corporate and Apple retail are two ENTIRELY different entities. Just because an employee enters the Apple "eco-system" at a base level doesn't mean that the employee may have a better chance of securing a corporate career, even with an adequate curriculum vitae and professional experience. Experiences seem like more of a way to "tease" employees rather than show a glimpse of a future career.
Advice to Management
Hit or miss. Mainly issues at corporate levels rather than direct store issues. Management styles shouldn't vary wildly manager to manager. Please keep employees up to speed and help them use outside sources to train. "Hello" and training modules exist but these tools are useless without ample time to actually study the material. Get some hands on physical basics (computer internals), new phones to practice basic iOS diagnostics/resets. SET ADEQUATE time aside for new hires to learn, I cannot stress this enough. The last thing you need is a new hire sheep waiting for help with a quick fix while management is dealing with unruly customers. It will only benefit in the long run. Some favoritism took place. We all know resources are limited and management at a store level won't change the entire company, but some more measures need to be implemented. For everyones sanity.

pros: You get a paycheck and you get to work from home
cons:
No managers or support even when customers are screaming at you. Many of my co workers are having mental health issues because of how this job is designed and Apple does not want to hear about it. It is so stressful. I've never worked in a place that I could not get support from a manager. It does not exist in this role. Imagine someone has purchased a $3000 laptop and it never arrived in the mail and they have been given the wrong info when they called before (and the time before that). Yep sorry no you can't speak to a manager because there aren't any and I'm working at home. It's just you and me on the phone and you're yelling at me and there's nothing I can do. For the first few weeks I felt like this was the second worst job I have ever had but now that I've done it for a few months, it's moved into the number one spot. I have nightmares and can’t sleep most nights. I dread sitting at my desk and taking a call because you never know what you’re going to get on the other end of the line. And the whole set up is right in the middle of my home so even when I’m not working, it sits there and I have to look at it. I can’t get away.
Advice to Management
Design this system differently so specialists can get a manager on the line to speak with customers who demand it. The world is different now and Apple needs to adapt.

review_title: Equal Parts Challenge and Reward - Not for everyone
pros: The benefit package is excellent, even for part-time employees. 401k, stock options, medical/vision/dental, a wide range of product discounts, and other benefits. You get to work with a lot of high-functioning, like minded people, which means you'll make a lot of friends. The pay is competitive for a retail job.
cons:
The job is as challenging as it is rewarding - and as of late the challenges outweighed the rewards. Pay is not negotiable and superior sales performance is given little to no consideration during your 'merit increases' which are 3.5-5% per year, once a year. 

The high customer traffic, high noise, bright lights, and being on your feet for 8-9 hours can be physically taxing. Full-time work during holiday and launch season can be draining. The customers in my area were typically high-maintenance types and were often difficult to deal with.

Advancing in the company is more about playing the political game than how well your actual job is being done, which frequently results in people being advanced to management and leadership positions who do not have the right hard skills or competencies for the task. A good leadership team can really shape your experience at Apple as much as the work you put into it.
Advice to Management
It was a different game 5-7 years ago; We took care of customers more and focused less on sales metrics. Be genuine in your approach. Be more discriminating in current and future hires and promotions.

pros:
- New ideas are encouraged
- Coworkers and peers are incredibly smart
cons:
- The Apple culture is changing for worse. What was once a prestigious tech company who had a passion for innovation and people has disappeared and turned into a powerhouse of labor exploitation. Expect long hours and little pay
- On average, Apple provides around 3% pay raises each year. This does not cover the increasing costs of living in Austin. It doesn’t matter how great of an employee you are, you should expect 3%. There is no reason to work hard.
- Apple does not care about the city of Austin or the citizens that live here. Apple takes tax breaks and incentives, while continuing to white-wash any culture out of Austin, contribute to awful traffic patterns, and keeping overall city wages stagnant.
- Utilizing time off benefits is frowned upon. Workload sits for you to complete when you return, negating any kind of "refreshment" you feel from being away
- No room for promotions. Management does not care about development or helping you explore other opportunities. 
- Management is constantly talking about how much money our department has saved the company (we’re talking millions of dollars), meanwhile a peer on my team is on food stamps.
- Many of my peers are struggling with mental health issues due to being overworked and not having enough time off. Apple’s health benefits barely cover any type of treatment for mental health issues. Even the “top tier” health insurance plan does not cover widely accepted mental health treatment and instead insurance encourages you to take Xanax.
- When we had on-site doctors, they were low quality and constantly gaslight you
Advice to Management
Remember that your employees are humans and many have families. We deserve to be treated better.

review_title: Drastic changes in the retail stores over the years
pros: Have good company Benefits for employees
cons:
Company thinks so highly of themselves too often
Advice to Management
During training you tell us that “we want to help you grow” but when the time comes they never do. Depending on what store your working in or the manager, some do really want to help the employee succeed. But in my store anytime you talk with a manager about wanting to grow, in-company career opportunities their not there to help. During Covid, I understand it’s hard times and they want to keep us safe, but I was hired as a sales specialist and made me work as an AHA advisor troubleshooting etc. I was never trained as a technician! I was trained as a sales representative. Felt like I was drafted in the military when they started making us work from home. I wouldn’t have a problem working from home if it was RCC (at home retail advisor). As an AHA it was too stressful and less pay for it too.

review_title: Excellent pay and perks but not great culture
pros:
For any position you get awesome salary. Additionally, you get discounts on Apple products upto 17 % for friends and family on every product but you are limited to 10 products of each category(10phones, 10 airpods, 10 macbooks etc). And for your personal use you get 27% but limited to one product of each category. 
You also get 500USD credit additionally for every 2 years. 

You get 15 % discount on stocks but you can just buy them you can only opt to buy shares from your salary and the company will automatically deduct the amount from the salary. It is similar to VPF where you choose the percentage of deduction. Here you can only choose from 0 to 10% of your salary to be invested in shares. You cannot additionally buy elsewhere for 15% discount. 
You can also avail 155000 INR for any educational courses that you need to do. 
During the pandemic they also reimbursed for furniture.
cons:
The work culture is good not that interactive. All of the decision making is in Cupertino(HQ) and if you want to contribute to the process then it is not possible. You don't even have someone in the leadership to collaborate with. They give the work and you have to do it, contrary to Amazon where if you propose something and the leadership finds it impactful then they give you the ownership and also collaborate with you on that idea/project. If you want to just work and leave then its great for you but if you want to do something more apart from usual work then the aforementioned applies.

The educational courses mentioned need to be relevant to your work that you are doing at Apple and if your work and the educational course are not in the same field you won't get reimbursed. 
Furniture reimbursement is limited to 100 USD(7000INR) which is quite less. You either get a good table or an ergonomic chair but not both. 

There are not much ad-hoc tasks apart from the daily work which is pretty monotonous and tiring.

For this particular role(grading analyst) they give you iMac and not Macbooks to work so WorkFromHome is not allowed under ideal conditions. Due to the pandemic the iMacs were transported to everyone's homes and WFH was established for the team. 
There is no transport provided by the company but that's manageable since they are paying a lot.

review_title: Definitely not the same company after Steve Jobs’ death!
pros: Supportive staff and management, as long as you only focus on metrics (sales & appointment times)
cons:
Apple Australia is SUCH a different company & culture than Apple in the US. Sales and service metrics are king, everything else falls by the wayside.
Don’t call in sick or take a personal day for work-life balance, you’ll be ostracized by leadership. 
Bullying is RAMPANT in Australian retail stores, when brought to leadership’s attention - they tell you that it must be you because you’re not assuming positive intent. 
Favoritism is everywhere and not hidden - be one of the cool kids or you’ll be left out of every opportunity.
Advice to Management
Bring back Steve’s vision, a fierce customer focus, and treat team members like part of the team. Get rid of the rampant bullying and favoritism and learn that harassment (however subtle) is never okay and should never be swept under the rug by HR after complaints.

review_title: Poor collaboration, incurious engineers, exploitative company
pros:
- Decent benefits and compensation for US based engineers
- That's it. That's why they get two stars instead of one
cons:
- Most team members I've worked with don't take pride in their work
- Directors and leaders often make decisions without consulting their teams, and then expect the team to execute on their commitments
- Discourse is usually based on making other people happy instead of making the best engineering decision
- Bugs, especially performance bugs, often go unfixed
- Leadership often has no concept of how to test products well or what kind of talent to hire to make that possible
- Most people only want to do the minimum amount of work to make their manager happy
- Will underpay labor if they can get away with it, especially outside the US
Advice to Management
The biggest change that would improve Apple's performance would be to make a much larger effort to let engineers work collaboratively instead of skate around their security guidelines. Apple should stop being so obsessed with having secret launches that don't even matter because most of their features have already been implemented by competitors. I have literally spent 8 work months of this year on product security, and it's not even my job.

pros: Benefits available for part time employees. Higher starting pay than many retail positions. Employee discount. International company means there are opportunities to keep your job if you relocate. Focus on improving hiring practices for diversity and inclusion. Employees kept on during Covid19 shutdown.
cons:
Toxic positivity at the retail level. Lack of clear and consistent messaging breeds distrust in management and the company at large. Cult-like atmosphere. Gaslighting from management. Management ignoring needs. Difficult to advance. Still hires disproportionate number of white men vs. women and POC. Stores not enforcing social distancing and safety rules during Covid19 reopen, employee safety put below bottom line even though Apple is more than rich enough to take the hit to ensure safety, especially considering retail stores only make up something like 8% of profits.
Advice to Management
At Apple Retail, we are taught to ask questions, listening, and acknowledge customer concerns so that we can have true empathy and align with them. We are constantly told that people are Apple's greatest priority. Employees need this basic respect, not just customers. We can't be treated like robots. If Apple wants retail robots, they can design them. Until then, employees need to be acknowledged and respected as human beings.

review_title: “Apple” is great. Apple, Inc. is ok.
pros: Great benefits. Fair pay. Wonderfully diverse culture. Good bonuses.
cons:
Typical corporate bureaucracy. Advancement is RARELY based on merit and experience. The constant drive for new talent is present in all positions so it is FAR more likely that someone from outside the org will end up your boss than someone whose been promoted. Or it will be someone internal but was transferred from another department. Individual achievements are not recognized. Your success is Apple’s success so know that you are a small cog in a big machine that won’t miss you when you leave. Apple will engulf every aspect of your life. More relatives will call you asking for help with their products than relatives would call you if you won the lottery.
Advice to Management
Fight for your team’s individuals’ professional development more than headcount.

review_title: Just above average pay for very long hours and being pushed to your limit.
pros:
You get to see the product road map up to 6-8 years out and it can be fun playing with new technology. You get to make awesome designs for great people.

You will learn a lot. Take advantage of their school reimbursement programs and any skill programs offered.

It will be the highest design standards you will work with in your career. Material, tolerances and finishes must be perfect.

Max our your stock options and when vested 401k.

You will learn cutting edge design methods and have excellent standards and practices.

Overtime is good, this can even go to double time in some cases. Having an extra 2-4 hours of overtime a day adds up. Just make sure to pace yourself and take care of your health.

There is always something to do.

If you love the brand it will draw you in and you will have a role in bringing Apple's products to life.

Your work will have an impact on millions of people.

You will do the work of a higher paid position so it will be nice to get that experience.

If you are doing good use this to get a higher position elsewhere, it will help you advance your career faster.
cons:
Management tends to be very self centered, not as much focused on growing your career but in growing their own. This can often cause tension as lots of people are vying for attention of higher ups. Expect to do all manner to tasks to help the team and your manager. Some will be menial but they will lead to more fun and complex projects over time. Make sure you do all your basic work before seeking to get to advanced work. 

There is not a lot of ownership of responsibility in management. Often they will kick downward. For example if they made a call on a design direction and it turns out that the higher ups do not like it they will blame the worker following their request in my experience. Do not count on accountability, however I would recommend if your manager is rude or does something out of line let Apple HR know immediately. It will save you a lot of hassle down the line.

Politics is huge at Apple. Pay very close attention. People will pretend to be your friend or interested in your work to make a connection. If you get too popular with higher ups in a different team management can punish you, even if you were doing your job. Have a pulse on politics. Rank is big at Apple.

Apple's biggest flaw is they rush themselves to the breaking point where for no reason. Often cutting already tight timelines for small reasons rather than give someone an additional 8 hours to refine a design. They can set the deadlines and standards but they often push people far beyond reasonable limits and in some cases the deadlines can be changed just as easily as they are set. In some cases I have worked 28 hours straight on a prototype that could just have easily been move out one day. This creates a scramble culture where you will be under a lot of stress often. You will be blamed for not doing work fast enough when often you can be given timelines that are not physically possible. In those cases be prepared to set expectations so you will not be taken advantage of.

The average day is 12 hours. During a build it typically goes until the project is done. This mind you will get you a 'meets expectations' on your review. Doing above average work is average for Apple standards. You need to go above even that or have a good political connection for the next level.

Often you will have to leave the company/position you are in to get a promotion of any value. Its such a waste that Apple does not help grow people's careers especially after investing so much time into them.

You will often be asked to do the work of others and get no credit for it, even if you do your own expiration be careful as your manager may take your idea. Document everything you do, this will help.

You will often be pushed to commit everything to work and be accessed at all hours of the day. Be careful in how you set boundaries as this can often lead to you not being seen as serious.

You will often do the work at a higher level than your current position but not be paid more for it. You will often help people make extremely complicated projects and get no real recognition for it.
Advice to Management
Recognize ambition and try not to make the career development of others about advancing your own career. Help build others up rather than try and take credit for the work of others.

Listen when people tell you something is wrong or if the person you manage is being bullied. Seriously, listen and help.

When you say you will push back and help with insanely tight deadlines, actually do it. I cannot say how many time we would have a meeting where we would all say the timeline is impossible, our manager would say "Yep I'll bring that up when we meet," then we all met and they would not say a word when the designer laid out their expectations and timeline.

review_title: If you're easily stessed, don't work here.
pros: Great pay, benefits for LGBT families including healthcare
cons:
Constantly shifting management, difficult to advance,
Advice to Management
At home advisors are micro-managed on so many different numbers. Your manager will constantly tell you there is something you can improve on. I've found that you can work for this company for a decade and still be stuck doing the same tasks in the same position. 

There will be peers you meet that moved up quickly and management will tell you it’s your fault if you haven’t transitioned into a higher role. You will have the same manager for about 6 months max, then they will take a leave of absence or go to a new department- so you’re stuck proving yourself to someone new. 

If you are chat support, they will expect you to help up to 3 individuals at once (4 if you are consulting with another department) and respond within 2 minutes while customers are asking “Hello, are you there?” and you are told to lie if the customer asks if we’re helping multiple people.

If you are not fast enough, they will question your ability and recommend you get medical help. Completely absurd.

Repair pricing for all devices is expensive for the average person. This truly is a luxury brand and you will find out soon enough when customers cannot afford the ridiculous prices this company wants to charge everyone for out of warranty repairs.

Bonuses are never received, but there are annual performance reviews typically followed by a 40 cent pay raise and heavily taxed Restricted Stock Units that you cannot touch for years. You will make good money working here, but you will be expected to devote all your time to helping customers in an extremely stressful, fast paced environment while staring at white space on a screen all day.

The major takeaway working for Apple- is that you’re working for a huge corporate conglomerate that overcharges for everything, and furthers capitalism in a way that has made humans codependent on our screens and immediate gratification.

pros: Their training for retail is particularly robust. I didn't find it difficult to go from training to on-the-floor, but it was a 3 day training process. They offer nice discounts and benefits available to those who are seasonal or part-time employees. You will not be able to avail of ALL discounts that Apple offers but there are quite a few you can manage to take advantage from while working there. I think your experience being a product specialist will also heavily rely on when you work at Apple and where. I was hired as a seasonal employee for the winter holidays in Los Angeles. It can be brutal with tourists bombarding you with question after question about discounts you are obviously unable to give them. I found the best people to work with to be the coworkers. They are diverse because Apple wants you to be diverse, which is nice, except that Apple's illusion of caring for diversity pretty much stops once it goes beyond the retail floor.
cons:
The kool aid drinking is beyond imaginable. It is cult like. They push real hard the sentiment that Apple is The Best Company in the World to Work For and Look At How Much We Care About Things. I think the company genuinely has more compassion that a few other tech giants but that's not saying much, to be honest. Also some of the store managers have an over-inflated ego about being store managers for an Apple store. But whatever floats their boats I guess.
Advice to Management
Please hire more diverse employees in... like... your C-level positions. It doesn't really mean anything when the people running your company are about as spicy as polonaise but you're proud of how diverse your retail employees are. It just means you like to exploit our image.

review_title: Struggling to stay and feel valued after 6+ years
pros:
-: The benefits are great. Dental, Vision, and health are just stellar. 
-: Reimbursement for gym is nice. 
-: Mental health support during COVID 19. 
-: Pay (DOE) is great. 
-: Great management. (There are some *amazing* ones)
cons:
-: Arrogant managers. (It really is hit and miss) Report one and you may put a target on your back. 
-: Isolation when you work from home wears on you after years of doing this, inability to move up in the company (the more you want to progress the fewer options/places there are)
-: The company seems to be blending politics with the work place (keep it out Mr. Cook)
-: Mandatory overtime
-: Policies change on a whim and you have to master things fast
-: your friends and family use you as their personal Genius Bar even at 2 am...
-: Burn out is real. 

If you can’t adapt to change fast and work under pressure, this is not a job for you. And no - you don’t get insider news when new phones drop, new tech is released, etc.
Advice to Management
-: Back in the day we used to feel valued. We would get random gifts from management in the mail (I know we get points now but - it was a welcomed surprise to get a t-shirt or journal every now and again) 
-: Our team meetings felt more laid back just a few years back and we didn’t feel rushed and business only. 
-: Taking away the people factor from those we work with makes it hard to stay connected to our job. Not all of us want to be friends with coworkers outside of work on social media or via text but we wish to be connected AT work. We want to know if there’s a trend to calls, if people are having a bad day and not be punished for it so we can rally around them, talk about a difficult customer so we can help them through it and handle it better next time. It’s a luxury I guess at home advisors don’t get.

pros:
- Fitness allowance
- Worked in a very talented collaborative team, can't emphasise this enough!
- Plenty of opportunity to level-up communication skills internally and with customers particularly in a flagship store
- Working in dynamic situations under competing pressures means similar situations in other contexts are a doddle now
- Attention to detail and people centred approach (to customer service & technology) Have not found this at other companies
cons:
- HUGE disconnect between marketing and reality particularly in regards to diversity and inclusion. Sadly there's no real commitment to seriously support and celebrate all employees, address genuine disparities or to listen and act on feedback in this regard whether on a store level or Cupertino.
-Management: lack knowledge and competencies across all areas of store including in customer conflict deescalation and resolution, some have bullying/gate-keeperish line management style, make decisions without input of people on the ground, physical and mental wellbeing of staff is not a priority.
- Cult like company culture leads to inability to publicly express a range of thoughts and emotions even outside of work
- high turnover particularly of shop floor colleagues particularly at Xmas
- Poor life/work balance due to scheduling
- No real opportunities exist connecting corporate to retail arm
- Pay is extremely low for what you actually do
- Upwards progression non existent due to favouritism and bias
- Made to feel very disposable and exploited
- Told Metrics/KPIs are not so important when you join but you soon realise they are seen as most important thing - even above customer experience
- Genius Bar 'Resets' are supposed to be a short well-deserved rest but instead become the primary way training is delivered
Advice to Management
You will haemorrhage talent if you do not invest in development and progression, whilst compensating and recognising your team's passion and craft. 'Positive intent' and 'feedback' are used so selectively disadvantaging some of the most vulnerable in the team. Listen and include your employees more and stop infantilising them -we are the one's physically running the show.

cons:

employee_title: Int Designer, Senior User Experience Designer, User Experience Engineer
pros:
- (subjective) As each of the 'most desireable' FANG companies has their own culture, Apple has theirs. Its a bit more low-key, professional and relaxed.
- after the initial shock of "I work at Apple now" fades away, work is work and your satisfaction/stress level will vary depending on your role, department, skill set and organization. I transferred between 3 different organizations - some very political, others like family. Sometimes within an org, 1 managers style (understanding, laid back - just expects quality work on time etc) would be a complete opposite of my coworkers under another manager (9-5 run like an agency)
- if you're ambitious there is opportunity - but also know there is a sautés quo and you are taking a risk. its up to you whether or not its worth it.
- looks great on your resume
cons:
Alot of politics, I've seen entire agencies brought in for single projects where the end result was scraped. I've seen managers hire relatives and Apple outsources their 'investigations' department who get paid by how many people they accuse of violating policies.
Advice to Management
Not to all management, but to those who contract security teams and to whoever made the decision that your personal iCloud account becomes you work account. you find this out during orientation but by then its too late to create a new Apple ID.

There's no opportunity for separation of "church and state" and as I experienced a "zero-tolerance" policy was enacted, there was no announcement and I was interrogated for violating it after being an above average (based on performance reviews) employee for ~4 years.

pros: The pay and benefits are decent. Working from home is pretty great at times, and you do get discounts on Apple products.
cons:

There is little to no career advancement.

Management is hit and miss. Your performance is also very arbitrary, and anything and everything that apple does is blamed on you. Customer has to pay for a repair? Your fault they're mad.

Listen to us and not dismiss our concerns as "negative". The kool aid is strong on this company

pros:
*Good salary & benefits
*Job stability at corporate
*Smart & some kind people if you look for them
*Good on your resume
*Opportunity to develop your political skills and patience
cons:
*Incredibly hard to onboard (& everyone reminds you about this regularly) beyond superficial stuff like IT & basic corporate tasks, especially during COVID. *So so many 10++++ year or "I've only worked at Apple" people. Apparently there's an "Apple Way" to do things but there's also little documented so hard to figure out what that means. 
*Related there's a wide belief that Apple is somehow particularly special (in a way that doesn't prove out imo) & there's an arrogance that goes along with it. This is not a company that values humility or listening.
*Unbelievably siloed based on function & product. Most organizations & even the next level teams might as well be separate companies.
*Your experience will vary incredibly based on which organization & which team you end up on. Ask a lot of tough questions about that during the interviews. What characteristics are valued?
*Your experience will also vary incredibly based on your manager so do your due diligence & insist on a lot of time talking to the manager before you accept a job at Apple.
*Not a company that feels fun or where a sense of humour seems valued. Yes COVID complicates this but we are all still human not robots.
*A lot of time spent talking in committees that go nowhere.
Advice to Management
For a large global tech company Apple is strangely committed to being an in person, butts in seats culture & has not pivoted smoothly to virtual work. This old fashioned approach is legacy from Steve Jobs & the long term executives from what I can tell. Employees are enjoying the freedom to WFH & are already grumbling about why they will always need to be in the office. This could be a big retention issue post COVID.

review_title: Apple Advisor role is a great step towards a fruitful IT career
pros:
• Very good leadership 
• Great training
• Positive team synergy
• Excellent benefits
• Awesome Employee Discounts
• Good HR Support
• Amazing brand recognition amongst family, friends, strangers, if discovered that you work for the company.
cons:
•Difficult to move up in positions as the company grows (not impossible, just more challenging)
• Once capped out in salary in a role, there is a great diminishment in merit percentages at annual reviews - forces movement up, or laterally in position
• Sometimes near obsessive-micro management practices from management in regards to Advisors maintaining specific call-center metrics (its a call center!)
• Not enough education -empathy practices for Apple management to help them in better working with mental health and stress management issues amongst their Apple teams and groups.
Advice to Management
My aforementioned pros and cons are strictly from my own perspective and not influenced by anyone else. 
I know and personally appreciate and respect a good number of the upper-management, area managers and team managers, I've had the pleasure of meeting and working for, and I have nothing to say other than I do empathize at the incredible fortitude you each must have and maintain, to function in the roles and at the levels you do.

 So in understanding the majority of roles in Apple leadership, I've been exposed to, I will never speak negatively about Apple management - they are some of the better leadership I have experienced in any job ever worked, but always room for more improvement.

Cannot state much else, other than to encourage Apple leadership to continue innovating and learning from their mistakes and miscues and to, continue to always keep" thinking different: because those good effective changes will eventually follow. I know they will because all my years with Apple I experienced spaces in time where I saw very good changes.

review_title: Truly special and unequaled company that taught me an immense amount and changed my life
pros:
• Incredible culture and drive to be and do the best at everything. Steve's simple yet powerful vision "to make the greatest products in the world" really did deliver.
• Special place to be and work alongside some really great and talented people. I was there for 8yrs and to this day have life long friends and trusted colleagues.
• IF you performed and achieved results, you could be compensated handsomely. This was obviously even more dramatic the earlier you joined (I joined around the time of the 1st iPhone). 
* Honestly, I miss so much about Apple despite it being my choice to leave. There was so much greatness there but I had to expand my horizons and in doing so have passed on immeasurable amounts of experience I gained while at Apple.
cons:
• Like any organization, there were some true jerks. They were somewhat few and far between but upper management did not see this clearly and HR was not good about dealing with them EVEN when there were multiple points of feedback. I had a Director that was such a jerk that it caused me physical health issues not to mention the emotional and stress toll. Luckily I was young and could take this, but MANY people quit or tapped out, I watched it happen somewhat frequently. That said, these horrible experiences were balanced out by some incredible leaders who to this day set the bar for me. 
• Tons of travel can really wear on you. If you get good at it, you can manage it, but nothing is like being home consistently. The good news is the travel is somewhat by choice -- once you prove yourself you can move around internally to minimize this -- and it's comfortable (good airline seats, good hotels, good food, good people).
• Career growth is challenging since there are so many motivated, driven, capable people. Even when you believe -- and others tell you -- that you are a stand-out performer and leader, there's always jockeying for roles and it can be exhausting and demotivating.
Advice to Management
Apple is a very special place, do everything you can to preserve the good. 
When it comes to management, work really hard to root out the bad apples (pun intended) and promote the great leaders -- the ones that people want to put it all on the line for, they are there and they are obvious if you look. Results are very important, but not the only measure and should not outweigh how someone treats others or the morale impact of jerks on the organization. I routinely wondered why certain people weren't fired let alone why they were promoted. This can be done better and is key to ensuring Apple remains a compelling place to be and work.

pros:

cons:
Don't be fooled by the 'Everything is awesome' vibe the managers try to put on, office politics are very real in every store and even though you will get along with most of your coworkers, you are competing with them if you want to advance anywhere.
Demands from head office feel very out of touch with what is actually happening in stores.
Managers get moved/removed often due to performance, politics, etc. so get what you can from a manager that you connect with because you never know how long it will last.
In 8 years of working at Apple, I've only heard of 2 people moving to corporate and both were due to connections to district management; if that was your plan to get into corporate I would highly reconsider that path.

review_title: Great company with a culture that takes getting used to
pros:
One thing I’ve learned from talking to people within Apple is your experience will greatly vary, depending on your organization. I’m a software engineer in the Core OS organization within SWE, so my review only applies to that.

People outside Apple like to poke fun when senior leadership publicly says they’re trying to be customer-centric and “do the right thing” while making decisions that go in to products. After being here, I truly believe that is the case! Tim and Craig have proven to be very thoughtful, honest and effective leaders

We work on some tough technical problems and some really innovative technology.

At the end of the day, as an individual contributor I am enabled to put my head down and do my best work. Apple can be demanding, expect to receive emails and pings on nights and weekends. You have to learn to set boundaries and stick to them. If you enjoy your work, like I do, it’s very easy to accidentally put too many hours in
cons:
As with lots of tech companies, there are many different personalities to deal with and some can make your job miserable. It sounds like being in middle management is extremely political and there are management movements / re-orgs pretty often.


Apple culture can be difficult to navigate for some. There’s very little documentation (this is improving), and the company is entirely built on making relationships and hallway conversations. This can make working in remote offices difficult, from what I’ve heard. Introverts beware!
Advice to Management
Keep doing what you’re doing, the company is doing very well

pros: Events on site, benefits, some great coworkers
cons:
tough schedule, overbearing management, constant flow of calls without many breaks. AppleCare is unique at Apple, and unlike any other department. While in AppleCare, you will be treated like a secondhand employee. Management will micromanage you, and if you are not taking a certain amount of calls per hour, will often talk to you. In other departments, Apple treats its employee's with a much more open "start up culture vibe", where employee's have the ease of a creative space. Not in AppleCare however. You are there to take calls and that is it. I would think of AppleCare culture more in line with a pyramid scheme or MDM culture, where your existence is simply to meet numbers. I have to quit simply for the mental anguish. Apple is a great company, and I still love Apple products and upper level management. If possible join another org.
Advice to Management
Apply the management used for other departments, don't micromanage.

pros: Great pay, great benefits and you have Apple on your resume.
cons:
Reviews are accurate, all of the bad ones at least. They use a lot of OFFSHORE contractors, and high percentage are not good, same for the managers, they used to be not so good contractors and are managers now.

Is not usually bad to use contractors due to the flexibility of scale up and down on people, but when you have 5 employees and 15 contractors and they just come and go, you don't really have that flexibility, it's the same 15 positions but filled but people that are taken to extreme burn out and writing code and creating designs worst than recent grads. Engineer quality is the worst I've ever seen in my life overall with 18 YOE. Are there good folks there? Yes, absolutely, but when you have 5 employees and 15 contractors and 50% suck and are OFFSHORE in India on a completely different timezone you are in for a mess and a career hara-kiri. 

Unless you are making much less than the current TC offered, I would advise against it. It doesn't matter the team, trust me on that, I have experienced and interacted with several teams, it's all the same. If TC is significantly higher take it, and leave soon to similar paying company. I'm looking for my way out.

All the contractors are from Tata Consulting and Infosys, those guys are suffering and being exploited. 100% of the people I've interacted with are Indians, diversity is 0%, it's incredible, you feel like you are in India yourself, never seem this in my life and I've worked in all the MAGAF.
Advice to Management
If you are going to have contractors, why not have them at least on similar timezone? Contractors are good for flexibility of scale resources up and down, but if you have a contractor for 5 years that mean it was never a temporary necessity, why have it at all if it wasn't quality engineer?

review_title: It’s like a call center in your home. Stress included
pros:
The pay
Team members 
Discount
cons:
This best thing about this job was the pay and the team members. After 6 months they start switching you around like clothes to other managers and groups. During winter and summer, full time is a huge pain because you literally work from home but can’t spend time with your family on the holidays since most of your day is taken by this job. The customers are ruthless, rude and use vulgar language this company cares more about what angry biased customers think than the employees. Most of your job performance is based on people that either don’t like the companies policies and give you a bad review or people asking you to take out a magic wand and grant their “impossible” wish. The managers are big on favoritism and they start tearing you apart once you let them know they can’t control you like the rest of the team. The tier 2 advisors and disgusting as well and take every chance to make you feel dumb for trying to do your job or not knowing something. This job starts off well but ends up to be a circus based off of how high you can jump to make the customer happy. The 8 hour shifts are grueling and having a kind customer was very rare for me. Being in college and dealing with a job like this was absolutely stressful and they don’t care for you to have a life. The hours to take off are limited and they literally try to penalize you for taking off WITHOUT pay when there are literally no more hours left to put in! The pay was always good but not all money is good money because this job is very stressful and has a lot of surprises that come up along the way. pros:
Really loved working at the Covent Garden store in London. The culture around Apple overall is amazing, and I wish all companies and employers were like this. Because it’s so important to work and get along with the people you see often at your job, and especially when things get really intense with the sheer volume of customers, it’s so good to have the balance of quality people working alongside you. I made incredible friends there, and when I have my own business, I hope to create an environment as accepting and fun and hardworking as what I had with Apple. Being able to speak with your manager as your equal is so important because it shows the respect throughout the entirety of the store between everyone working there, and all aiming to achieve the same end goal. And literally the most fun I ever had at a job!! So grateful! 

Another pro is that Apple really values customers as people, as employees are. There’s no forced sales on anyone. As specialists our jobs are to *inform* customers about products and services. It’s about having that conversation with them and getting to know them so you can better direct them to their needs. This really stood out for me because it wasn’t about selling the products, but really helping people. That’s a big passion of mine 😊
cons:
Retail anywhere can be exhausting and overwhelming. I’m just glad Apple is the way it is to make it so much better and bearable. I wish the way retail operates in general should change. It’s a very long time being in your feet. By the time you finish your shift, you suddenly stop rushing around and you feel like you could collapse. Customer assuming everyone they talk to works directly for Apple, and they know how much we make, so we should kiss their butts, and allow them to be rude and demeaning no matter what. pros:
-Good pay BUT not consistent across all at the same job title/tenure
-Benefits available for full and part time employees
-Generous stock grants (RSUs)
-Good maternity/paternity leave policy
-I have been told the health insurance is great, although I did not personally use it so I can't say firsthand. 

Overall, Apple Retail has some high highs and low lows. I tried to document my experience as well as possible, and honestly ended up writing much more than I had originally intended. I do want to add the disclaimer that although there is a big block of text in the "CONS" section, I did enjoy working at Apple. I liked my job there, paid me well and I got valuable experience. Was it something I'd do as a career? No. Was it a good stepping stone in my professional development? Absolutely. I write this feedback not to slander Apple but to give a genuine account of my experience, prepare others who are considering joining Apple, and hopefully help Apple Retail improve for the sake of all Apple employees. 

At Apple, I had the privilege of meeting people with all kinds of different backgrounds, education levels, and experiences. Even now that I have moved on, several of my mentors at Apple continue to push me to improve. I can genuinely say that Apple was the most diverse company I have ever worked for, and yet it wasn’t a gimmick or to fill a quota. It felt like you could be your genuine self and I would say that I felt very welcome there. 

I experienced a tremendous amount of personal and professional growth during my time there. If you had asked me before I started, I would never have described myself as a leader and yet by the end of my time at Apple, I had led initiatives, coached/mentored my peers, and established myself as a leader, resource, and mentor. I learned how to talk about myself and the work I’m doing in a concise way (STAR / SBO). I learned how to collaborate with people with different work styles from my own, how to provide feedback in different ways based on how the person best receives it, and I learned how to challenge and be challenged without damaging my relationship with my colleagues. I learned a lot about my own worth as an employee and how to advocate for myself. I learned to seek to understand, to approach mistakes as opportunity for shared growth rather than an opportunity to place blame, and how to be empathetic even when it is easy not to be. 

Some of the best managers I’ve ever had were from Apple. These managers were not afraid to jump into the fray when we were at our busiest. They empowered my colleagues and I to make the call in a tough situation and backed us up on whatever we felt was best. They trusted us to do our jobs well and always sought to understand before giving feedback or calling out problems if they arose. They went to bat for us against managers who were quick to dismiss our talents.
cons:
For context, I was one of the top repair technicians and consistently rated within the top 3 in the store for repair quality and timeliness from the time I received my ACiT (Apple Certified iPhone Technician) certification. I passed my ACMT (Apple Certified Mac Technician) certification with a 97% (68 questions correct out of 70). In addition, I have prior experience building computers and have a solid grasp on how computers work / what hardware components do. 

No repercussions for calling off so it wasn’t uncommon for 5-6 people to call off a day.

At the Genius Bar, they consistently prioritized personality types over technical skill when considering candidates. Storewide, great candidates were consistently passed over in favor of more vocal candidates. It was also not uncommon for managers to play favorites, and some managers would actually do their best to undermine your development if they didn’t like you.

I believe that while skills can be taught, attitude is a key point of your personality and is not so easily changed. However, for this model of hiring the person, not the skill, there needs to be sufficient training to get the person up to a functional standpoint. I would say Apple has done a lackluster job when it comes to technician training the past few years. Genius (Mac technician) training consists of two weeks off the sales floor doing self-guided online trainings (few of which that actually apply to the service being provided), a certification assessment, and a week of repair shadowing. After that point, the new Genius can do their first repair ON A CUSTOMER'S MACHINE. Customers pay a lot of money for the products and a lot of money for repairs. It is absolutely unacceptable that the first computer a technician takes apart is a paying customer's machine. In addition, nearly all of the other Geniuses had no computer experience outside the Genius Bar. The troubleshooting process for most of my former peers is just pattern matching reported symptoms with support guides and regurgitating solutions. 

Despite being the youngest Genius on my team and the least tenured in the role, I regularly had to fix the mistakes of my peers. Some examples of repair mistakes include putting screws in the wrong location, not plugging in antenna / mic / camera / battery connectors before marking a repair as ready for customer pickup, not taking security precautions when dealing with batteries, leaving ESD sensitive components sitting out uncovered for hours at a time, bending a pin on a logic board, and more. I also had to reset customer expectations after one of my peers advised a customer that her new iMac wouldn’t run any faster than her 2013 iMac because they both had HDDs. The issue the customer was experiencing was no more related to the HDD than Java is related to Javascript (read: not related at all). In the end, I was able to fix the issue but the customer had clearly lost faith in the Genius Bar and honestly, I can’t blame her for that. 

The biggest issue though, in my opinion, was the inconsistency in management. The managers were either amazing or the worst, no in between. See my experience with the good ones in the “Pros” section. The bad managers, though, were awful. Micromanagement, lack of trust, and blatant favoritism were common. These managers clearly prioritized the customer in the store rather than the customer with a device awaiting repair. Mac repair consisted of 1-3 technicians (normally 1 on weekdays, 2 on fri/sat, 3 for special occasions), occurred only once per day for 2-3 hours maximum (normally 2), and yet at least one Mac technician was pulled to the floor early on a nearly daily basis causing a never-ending cycle of late repairs and angry customers. 

The store leader was the worst, in my opinion. They had no knowledge of Genius Bar processes yet frequently made (impossible) requests of the technicians. Example: a customer came in with a device with no accessible device identifier (missing SIM tray = no IMEI, would not turn on so no S/N, and the serial reader tool didn’t retrieve anything from the phone). The customer was advised that ideally the SIM tray would be needed or at minimum a proof of purchase to service the device as the internal ticketing system was tied to the device identifier (SN) and there was no way to create a repair / replacement for the device without it, even as a customer service exception. The customer started to escalate and get visibly upset, so the store leader got involved and after being informed of the situation, advised the technician to just replace the phone (a common exception when a customer is escalated). Except that there was no possible way to systematically replace the phone. Even if the technician took a phone off the shelf and gave it to the customer, there would still be a litany of issues preventing the customer from using the replacement. This is only one of countless examples.

review_title: It’s what you make of it
pros:
The biggest pro about working with Apple is the benefits.
Health insurance is top tier with nominal premiums.
RSUs, ESPP, EPP+, discounts on cell services, discounts with retailers and lots of other perks. 
Gym reimbursement if you don’t work on any of the campuses, bike reimbursement, or pays for commuter services.
The company is there for their employees during natural disasters, etc. 
Free legal advice if you’re going through matters outside of work.
Free therapy sessions if needed throughout the year. 
So many free or highly discounted services and products provided to us. 

In addition, the amount of opportunity for growth to corporate is unparalleled. If you leverage a career experience or mentor ship well enough, there’s no way you won’t open doors to corporate. (from a retail level)
cons:
At the retail level, it’s turned into a “good old boy” hierarchy. Market team leaders being brought in from clothing or big box retailers, hiring all their old buddies as lower leadership. It’s how our retail culture is being lost. Positive intent only thrives within employees that are considered “legacy” thinkers. And “legacy” thinkers don’t get promoted. Work/Life balance does not exist within Apple Retail, even for part timers. 

At the corporate level, it’s a scramble to fill positions. So we’ve hired so many people that aren’t top tier talent anymore. Friends hiring friends for the sake of friendship, instead of how they can actually perform. Pay is also not as competitive as other companies in SF/Bay Area/San Jose. 

They don’t like hiring from within for management positions. There are some really great employees and people that I worked with that should’ve been management a long time ago, but they’re quickly passed over.
Advice to Management
Promote from within, invest in the development and promotion of employees that have busted their butt for the company for decades. Be honest and truthful with feedback, don’t just sandwich people with BS.

review_title: Great pay, smart people, high standards, but poor work-life balance, poor management, and lack of healthy culture
pros: Highest paying employer in hardware by far. Mostly consists of smart and hardworking people, with very high standards for quality all around, which motivate you to work harder, more thoroughly, and think deeper than I ever have before. Apple also pushes you to learn how to be bold, demand highest quality in service and engineering work from coworkers and vendors, it promotes a culture of candid, instant feedback, and accountability. Working at Apple is fierce, can be militant like at times, but it will toughen you up and teach you a work ethic and approach of rigor likely unparalleled.
cons:
The demands for work load and quality are so high it can be extremely exhausting, stressful, and bad on your health and life outside of work. You are generally expect to not have a life outside of work during the work week. In some hardware groups you will be working until 10p-2am every night.
Advice to Management
Continue to keep the standards of quality high, but put more emphasis on work life balance and promoting healthier practices. Managers seem to be promoted mostly on technical ability and strongest ability to articulate problems, find solutions, and ability to put people in their place, lead meetings and discussions most fiercely. However not much emphasis seems to be put on promoting leaders who are good at motivating people in a healthy way, instead they promote motivation by fear / aggressive deadlines. 

Incorporate healthier practices into management training. Lead by example. Teach managers to motivate people through positive encouragement rather than negative punishment and fear.

pros: Apple Retail gives you the ability to pursue or experience many different jobs and roles. Also, if you're willing to move, you can get a job in any county that has a retail location. Great "family" aspect where you can make life-long friends. Apple Retail is a great starter job to fine tune certain competencies and areas of your personal and professional life. Easy work environment with a large support system.
cons:
Retail work environment, which results in dealing with the public in a large capacity. Intense feeling of being treated like a child. No relocation packages for retail employees who wish to transfer. High level of internal politics. A "blanket pay scale" that doesn't take into account the specific duties and responsibilities of each job title or employee. No work-from-home benefits or free lunches. No annual bonus for retail employees and a non-commission based salary. Lack of incentives to maintain a high level of performance. Cult-like work environment - constant need to "drink the cool-aid." Specific roles within retail do not transfer well to other industries.
Advice to Management
Management has been overall good. They typically leave you be when they feel that you're confident in your role. My advice would is: be more proactive in getting to know your employees on a one-to-one basis. Proactively plan for their present and future at Apple or beyond.

review_title: At the end of the day it is a sales job.
pros:
Great on-boarding process, even for part time season workers. Lots of classic Apple, feel good, cult vibe. Company mission is lofty. Relatively flat managerial hierarchy means you can approach anyone on the floor for help without getting an "That's not my job" or "I'm too important to ask" attitude. The majority of my co-workers were friendly and helpful. Again, very little attitude towards new people. Met some interesting and friendly folks.

25% discount for you. 10% discount for friends and family.

People team kept things interesting with fun and weekly events.

$19 hr decent rate for retail.

Upfront about seasonal work opportunities to stay and general attitude towards workers.
cons:
If you ever buy anything at Apple and get a survey PLEASE FILL IT OUT. You have no idea how much it means to the person who sold you your device. Fill out the whole thing!

After all the rah rah APPLE IS GREAT dies down it is a sales job. For the most part Apple products sell themselves. Most people tend to know what they want. They come to the store for the Apple experience. After that you're being judged on stuff like adding AppleCare+, Apple Business introductions and other metrics. 

Training feels rushed. 3 weeks of partial drilling of sales highlights. Too much to know for the incredibly complicated world of products, cell phone plans, AppleCare+ and Genius Bar. Basically they pound you full of the overview and you'll pick up the rest on the floor. 

Seasonal workers are exposed to the benefits and perks of the full time employees but can't participate. Feels bad. You get some of the benefits but not others and it is often not clear.

Had more experienced staff snipe business referrals from customers I was working with.

I had one interaction with my team leader in 4 months. Nice guy but felt very uninterested in our team growth. I'd be curious to see what the retention was per team related to the team leaders.

Had coworkers tell me they avoided taking customers who appeared to be from abroad due to the likelihood that they wouldn't be able to attach AppleCare+ to a sale and drive down their numbers. Managers seem to be oblivious to that fact.

Constant drumbeat for retail employees to care and give back to the community with employee donations and volunteering. Asking people making $25k a year to donate and volunteer for things felt weird. While they are all very earnest and good causes, they should be teaching financial planning seminars more often. The amount of coworkers spending their paychecks back into Apple was astounding.

Seasonal workers are expected to put in time on their own development despite not having access to the tools the full time staff have. It is unclear when you're supposed to put in this time as your work week if fully scheduled.
Advice to Management
Not much can be said. It's corporate so everything comes from the top. The local store leaders just work the latest commands into the flow. They all seem to walk the tightrope of corporate kool aid and knowing how the world really works quite well.

pros: Great company to work for. They look after their staff. You cannot expect to just get by. You have to find interest in the job and work hard and the rewards are worth it. Good pay and offers shares and free health insurance and gym reimbursement to encourage a healthy life.
cons:
