pros: Company always hires great people. Very rarely will you work with people who don’t pull their weight. Great benefits. Pays well for what it is.
cons:
Corporate keeps technicians in the dark about issues with the products and then expects them to do their dirty work explaining it to the customers with little to zero info. Forcing “part time” employees to have 30 hours of availability during the week. Rule school or your second job out! The work is brutal. Customers are mostly either neutral or nasty. Work there for a year, lock in your passion in the mean time, and then get out of there! I am not writing all this out of bitterness. I left on good terms and am still re-hireable. I worked at three different locations and just want people to know what to expect under the hood. You WILL encounter these issues.

Relate to the employees better. Be transparent. Explain issues with the products in scientific detail so the employees can give good solid info to the customers about why they are paying $300 plus dollars for something that isn’t their fault. review_title: Remnants of what it used to be... but with enormous career benefits
pros:
From a senior designer perspective across multiple orgs and 5 years
- resume booster / career validation
- great if your satisfied with the status quo and want a paycheck to retire with
- you can say you work at apple if that sort of thing matters
- if you get on the right team, there are awesome people there
cons:
- inconsistent creative direction or vision
- groups within the same org can function 110% different ranging from the 9-5 group to the laid back results oriented group.
- politics and stereotypes internally abound. Was “let go” after a lengthy investigation on a violation of a policy enacted 2 years after I was hired. No psa of new zero tolerance policies, or so they said. 
- certain orgs acquire agencies and they bring that dynamic with them. Most of the time they’re siloed which is good but if you’ve been part of an agency you probably don’t want that culture in your day to day anymore
- if you want benefits (snacks, stocked fridge) , salary at the higher end of the scale and have an impact on what you’re contributing as a designer, this might not be the place for you. If you just had a baby, bought a house, need stability or building your resume now is a good time. But the culture shift will catchup with the rumors as well as the numbers in the coming years.

No hard feelings, great time while I was there and wouldn’t change a thing. Easy finding an engaging mid 6 figure position elsewhere. Companies also match RSUs you might’ve lost out on. Mostly I miss the people and my team, but unfortunately losing faith in where the company is headed... I wouldn’t accept a position again considering the current climate within most major design orgs.
Advice to Management
Some of you are awesome and I owe a lot of my success to you. I’ll be forever indebted. Others don’t have the qualifications to be where they are, but got there bc of politics and nepotism. Thanks to the former!

review_title: Lovely Place to Work - Not Suitable for All Though
pros:
Work from home - can be very comforting to work in your own home office and not have the pressures or dress code. They supply all the equipment and reimburse internet bills
Health insurance, dental care, vision care
Employee discounts and friends & family discounts
Store credit issued every 3 years
Down to earth managers
Time allotted every week for self training
Easy job - 3 weeks of classroom training and another 2 weeks of easing into the role. After a month it's easy to settle in and if not, the help is always there from managers or senior advisors who are very approachable
cons:
Working from home is also a con as well - the novelty can wear off after some time and it's not for everybody as it can get very lonely and isolating after a while. Especially if your struggling
Work is very metrics based, too focused on stats and numbers
Peer feedback system which people use and abuse to badmouth you to your manager simply if they didn't like you (although this will be taken into account by the manager whether to send the feedback to you or disregard it)
Work is repetitive, mostly calls
Can be very hard to book time off or get the shift you want. This is based on a bidding process which to be fair is a good motivator but even if you're doing great you can never get weekends off
Career opportunities if you don't work in cork are limited. You can progress up the management line but if you don't want to work in tech or in any customer facing role the opportunities simply aren't there
Advice to Management
Try to be more inclusive of work from home advisors, the job can be very isolating and makes it more difficult when you've no one around you. A simple catch up every now and then outside of scheduled meetings to see how we're doing personally and mentally can do the world of good for feeling like we're supported and motivated.

review_title: Team is great, Customers not so much
pros:
The team at my store was perhaps the most diverse and interesting group of people that I've ever met, and I would not have been able to meet people like them were it not for Apple. Everyone is willing to help you out when you've got a problem/dealing with some ambiguous situations so there should be little reason for feeling nervous or unsure about how the day is going go.

The employee benefits are fairly generous, with relatively large discounts on products for both yourself and friends+family. Apple will reimburse you up to a certain amount for fitness related expenses like a gym membership.

I managed to secure a fairly good work/life balance at Apple, however I'm not sure about others.

Probably good for the CV?
cons:
Like in any customer service position, the customers are the most painful part of the job. Some difficult interactions would have been avoidable if AppleCare support and Apple stores were on the same page regarding things such as the availability of appointments and other specifics.

Managing customer expectations is also something that could be improved on within stores between sales and support, though management are always actively taking efforts to improve that.

The hourly rate is below market average.
Advice to Management
The most painful part about the job is dealing with customers who have either not been informed, or been misinformed about the support that we can provide. Both are very difficult issues to rectify, but if possible, it would greatly increase the smoothness of the customer experience.

cons:
Some employees do not like innovation, progress or change and it maybe hard to work with them in the same team.

I accepted the role because the hiring managers were so enthusiastic about innovation at every level of their organisations and were very welcoming of the people with similar mindset and culture. But there are other people working in entry-level positions for many years who can't stand any innovation and improvement initiatives and, therefore, create a toxic environment for work. Please, create more motivational opportunities for these kind of people, they need to feel they are advancing in some ways and make sure you have great like-minded people within the same team, otherwise the work will not be done as expected and the environment will not be healthy and/or productive for the company.

pros: Working at Apple is a unique experience that will be like no other company. You work with some of the most amazing people who are talented in a wide range of talents. You learn so much from your team members you'll always utilize them as a resource and they soon become family. The culture here is definitely unique and coming from a commissioned background, as far as sales goes, cut-throat and vindictive behaviors aren't encouraged. Moving up and growing is fairly simple, work hard, build a good rapport, and your work should be noticed. The benefits are amazing: top of the line health, dental, and vision insurance, education and fitness reimbursements (if you work near or at a campus they typically have gyms on campus for roughly $5), medical consultation form Stanford University, 3rd party corporate discounts, RSU and ESPP (Employee Stock Purchase Program) and so much more! Every few months there's something called NPP (Net Promoter for out People) in which the company asks us for our feedback for things to implement change.
cons:
Working in retail is tough. The leadership team can sometimes micromanage while not assuming positive intent which is frustrating. My local leadership team tells you "you own your own development" but give you no direction or coaching. When first starting with the company you get a lot of training for your role, but unfortunately no training around our company's amazing benefits and how to utilize them, and when it's time to use them you're typically scrambling to get a hold of your resources.

review_title: It’s a pleasure working for this company
pros:
Everyday I’m excited to go to work knowing that I’ll be helping people, finding out new things about the various devices or just engaging with my colleagues.

The thing about Apple, it’s not designed to be a hard sell company. I don’t look to hard sell you the iPhone, in fact, Apple’s marketing should garner enough interest in you already, I just want to lead you to a place where you may/may not see an Apple product working well for you.

Let’s talk about support. Out of all the other consumer electronics manufacturer out there, who offers such a diverse support system, whether at home, out and about or even in a different country. I have the confidence that if something goes wrong with my phone or iPad or MacBook, I know who to go first.
cons:
I have suspected that management can be a little off. Meaning some don’t have as enough technical expertise as I’d hoped, some lack in people skills and some you don’t see at all. 

In addition, they talk very well about reaching your full potential, but with that comes a game of favouritism. If they love you, they’ll put in good word, if not, well, you may as well just remain a specialist!
Advice to Management
Be proactive in employee engagement and development. There are some employees who have spoken to me about wanting to do something to build their character and have been shot down. I don’t want to have to do your own work. If it needs be, you step down and I’ll take your place.

review_title: Best retail job, but not perfect.
pros: Great overall environment with coworkers. Allowed for some individuality - both in wardrobe expression and daily operations.
cons:
Dealing with customers is certainly a part of retail, but we get a lot of heat from customers from decisions that corporate makes. And then, most of the time, we give the customer what they want anyways. Not to say that's wrong, but it messes with the standards and adds to the "other Apple Store does it" argument.
Additionally, as a part time employee hours can range from 15-30 hours per week - at least that's what the paperwork says. I was getting scheduled for about 28 hours a week consistently while also in college. This was fine until I realized that my academics were suffering, so I went to my managers and asked to reduce my hours. I was denied that because "there aren't enough people...we need you...we have to have everyone on deck for Saturdays and Sundays". That's certainly fair, but I didn't believe it when I saw leave requests getting approved left and right and continuous callouts throughout the whole section going unstopped.
My biggest gripe was the lack of scheduling flexibility.
I heard that there was room to grow and experiment with different jobs, but never got to experience that as I eventually ended up having to quit after a long attempt to reduce hours.
When I started not "meeting standards" for my position, I asked to move to a different section. I was again denied by basically being told to "just do better" in all aspects of my life - even after I said that this job was affecting all aspects of my life negatively and I really thought that moving out of my section would be better for everyone.
Advice to Management
Actually try to find a solution that works for both the employee and the Store. This is a great company to work for - when you can meet their needs.
